loans.name: Mom's Group

texts.en: This group loan has four people, located in Kou Duol village, in Takeo province. They will each use a share of this loan for different purposes. Mrs. Mom S. is a group leader, as selected by all the members. She is 49 years old. She is a farmer who owns a half-hectare of land to grow rice to sell to support her family. Besides this, she is also a pig breeding. Since her breeding is going well she wants to expand her business. So to improve her breeding, Mrs. Mom S. is applying for a loan to buy more piglets for breeding. Her husband, Mr. Pha B., is a construction worker. She is a mother of two children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory, while the other is attending a local public school.

loans.use: To buy more piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Nerguibaatar

texts.en: Nerguibaatar is 31 years old and lives with his mother in Arhangai province, Mongolia. They live in a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent called a “ger.”  They have lived there for seven years. Nerguibaatar currently operates a clothing business with support from his mother. He started his business in 2004 with capital of 1,200,000 MNT and has built it to a consistent level. He attributes success to his strong selling and communication skills. Today, his working capital exceeds 3,500,000 MNT. He has built a loyal customer base that appreciates his quality products. Nerguibaatar is requesting a 3,500,000 MNT loan to purchase more products to sell from Ereen, a popular trading town on the border with Mongolia.

loans.use: to purchase more apparel

loans.name: Dashiimaa

texts.en: Dashiimaa T. is 41 years old and lives with her husband and four children in Arhangai province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger — a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Two of her children, ages 17 and 15, attend a local secondary school. Her 13 year-old daughter, Jalbaajav, attends a local primary school. They have been living in their current home for two years. Dashiimaa operates a trucking transportation business which she has done since 2009 and has quickly found success. Her business earnings have enabled her to purchase a plot of land with a yard for her family. Dashiimaa has good communication skills and has many plans for the future including building a house for her family. Dashiimaa is requesting a 1,700,000 MNT loan to purchase spare parts to make repairs to her truck.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is a single woman with two children, one girl and one boy, both of whom attend school. She has been selling clothes both new and second hand for two years. She sells the clothes at the market to both men and women customers. She hopes to buy one bale of clothes with the KES 40000 loan.
	
Her major business challenges are seasonality as she experiences low sales during rainy seasons, and finding the best supplier for the clothes. She hopes to open a boutique in future. 

She decided to join Yehu because it offers its loans at a lower interest rate. Sarah rents a house with electricity and no water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

loans.use: To buy one bale of clothes

loans.name: Delgermaa

texts.en: Delgermaa D. is 45 years old and lives with her husband and five children in Baynhongor province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger or traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her husband, Batjargal, is disabled and currently receives assistance from the government. Their five children range in age from 6 to 26. One daughter, Lhamsuren currently works and studies in Korea. Delgermaa became a professional hairdresser in 1983 and has been  working out of the same rented shop ever since. Delgermaa's good work is well known among her customers. She hopes to one day own her own workplace and update her old equipment. Delgermaa is very hardworking and in her free time grows vegetables for her family's use. She is requesting a 2,200,000 MNT loan to purchase new equipment for her business.

loans.use: to purchase a hair dryer and other equipment

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria I. is from the town of Banga. She is 40 years old and married with three school-aged children. To make a living, Gloria grows rice for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over 17 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

Gloria joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gloria is requesting a loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure and other farming supplies. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Gloria from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children and improve the living conditions of her family. 

About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure and other farming supplies

loans.name: Enhsaihan

texts.en:
Enhsaihan Y. is 32 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Arhangai province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her two oldest daughters both attend a local secondary school and her youngest hasn't yet reached school age.

Enhsaihan currently operates a woolen souvenirs and accessories manufacturing business in her town with the help of her husband. They produce a variety of woolen souvenirs and accessories. Their products are very popular among their many customers due to their good quality and unique style. Enhsaihan gained experience in her trade by participating in a training for manufacturing woolen souvenirs and accessories in 2001. Since that time she has been operating her business and has built a loyal customer base.

Her business has been quite profitable, especially during the summer when a large number of tourists come through her area. Enhsaihan has used her earnings to purchase a plot of land with a house and yard for her family. She is an honest person and focused on the future. She hopes to one day have her own souvenir factory. Enhsaihan is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase raw materials for her business.

loans.use: To purchase unprocessed wool

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
51-year-old Helen F. is from the town of Banga. She is married and has three adult children. She has been involved in rice farming for more than six years. She also owns a sari-sari (variety) store located at her house. While her husband does the major farming tasks, she spends her time managing the store and making sure her family is happy. She earns approximately PHP 3,000 from the farm and store.

In 2009, Helen joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Helen has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Helen is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs and also additional inventory for the sari-sari store. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Helen from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About CEVI:
Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients, but also savings, insurance, and training, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs, as well as inventory for the variety store

loans.name: Gerlee

texts.en: Gerlee V. is 42 years old and lives with her husband and three sons in Baynhongor province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent called a “ger.” Her oldest son, Dandorj, attends university. Her middle son, Tsedendorj, attends a local secondary school. Her youngest son, Batzorig, is in primary school. Gerlee operates a recycling business in her town. She collects and sells bottles and plastic containers for recycling. She has been operating her business since 2008 and has steadily expanded her business. Previously, Gerlee operated a second-hand products trading business between 2003 and 2008. She is an experienced trader who has great communication skills. Gerlee is an industrious person and has many plans for the future. She says, “My dream is to one day create my own recycling factory.”  She is requesting a 1,800,000 MNT loan to increase her working capital and to rent another storage place for the materials to be recycled.

loans.use: To rent storage facility for recycling business

loans.name: Sharip

texts.en: Sharip N. is 52 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Bayn-Ulgii province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. They have been living together in their current home for 10 years. Sharip operates a taxi service in his town. He has worked as a driver since 1976. Sharip began his career as a driver for a governmental organization between 1976 and 1989. In 1989 he began transporting coal with his car. Sharip started his current taxi service in 2006. His oldest son, Shalhar, also operates a transportation business with his Russian microbus. He transports his customers to and from Ulaanbaatar and Ulgii. Sharip is an open person and has many plans for the future. His family and business are both very important to him. Sharip says, “I would like to build a house for my son.” He is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase spare parts for his cars.

loans.use: To purchase spare car parts

loans.name: Umirbek

texts.en:
Umirbek K. is 26 years old and lives with his wife and son in Bayn-Ulgii province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent.

Umirbek operates a clothing trading business in his town. He started his business in 2003 and has made much progress over the years.  Umirbek purchases his products from Taikeshken, a Chinese border town, and resells them for a profit with the help of his wife. Currently, his working capital is 3,000,000 MNT.

Since he started his business, his family's living conditions are greatly improved. He is a hardworking person and focused on the future. Umirbek has been planning to save money to support his family and invest in the future of his business. He is requesting a 3,500,000 MNT loan to purchase a variety of clothing from China.

loans.use: To import a variety of clothing from China.

loans.name: Mbula

texts.en:
Mbula is a married woman with four children, 3 girls and 1 boy. They all attend school. Her spouse sells spare parts. Sarah operates a grocery and also sells paraffin fuel. She hopes to buy more vegetables for her grocery and also buy five-20 litre containers of paraffin. She has been in the business for 5 years and previously was unemployed. She sells her products to her neighbors. She obtains other income from farming.

Her greatest business challenges are seasonality as she experiences low customer turn up during rainy seasons. She hopes to open a shop in the future. 
		
She decided to join Yehu after she saw other women benefiting from loans. She owns a house with neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees.

loans.use: To buy vegetables and  five-20 litre containers of paraffin

loans.name: Crisanto

texts.en:
Crisanto N. is from Barangay Tucal, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 61 years old. Crisanto is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Crisanto owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector planting and harvesting rice for sale. Crisanto has been engaged in his business for over 30 years and earns approximately 45000 PHP per harvest.

In 2008, Crisanto joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Crisanto has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Crisanto is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to pay for services to increase crop yield. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Crisanto from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About ASKI:

loans.name: Unurbek

texts.en:
Unurbek is 33 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Hovd province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent called a “ger”. Two of his children attend a local secondary school.

Unurbek operates a taxi service and vegetable planting business in his town. He grows potatoes and watermelons at his 0.6 hectare plot of land from which he sells to his customers. Unurbek is a very hardworking person and strives to provide a better life for his wife and children.  He is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to enable him to increase his vegetable output this year.

loans.use: To plant vegetables

loans.name: Tsetsegbayar

texts.en:
Tsetsegbayar is 26 years old and lives with her husband and daughter in Arhangai province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a 'ger', which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her husband, Erdenehuu, operates a taxi service and always supports Tsetsegbayar's business. 

Tsetsegbayar operates a beauty products trading business in her town. She started her business in 2005 with working capital of 500,000 MNT. After years of successful operations she has managed to increase her working capital to a level exceeding 1,300,000 MNT. 

Tsetsegbayar has built a loyal customer base and gained significant experience over the past five years. She is an honest person and focused on the future. Tsetsegbayar always tries to supply high quality products to her customers. She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase beauty products for her business.

loans.use: to purchase beauty products

loans.name: Hope

texts.en:
Hope D. P. is from the village of Christine Village, District 1, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 28 years old, is married, and has one school-aged child.

Hope owns and operates a business venture into food sector which is making and selling food, she prepares and sells crackers (a kind of snack) in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Hope joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI.

Hope is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be her sixth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

She is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her sixth from ASKI. Luzviminda plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children’s tuition fees. loans.name: Leticia

texts.en:
Leticia C. is from the village of Christine, District 1, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 59 years old, married, and has six adult children.

Leticia owns and operates a general store, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Leticia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her sixth from ASKI.

Leticia plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 


About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ireneo

texts.en:
Ireneo S. is from the town of Banga. He is 32 years old. Ireneo is married and has a 4-year-old child. To make a living, Ireneo owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Ireneo has been engaged in his business for over 9 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

Ireneo joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ireneo is requesting a loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. This will be the first loan taken out by Ireneo from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house to rent out.

loans.name: Norberto

texts.en:
Norberto D. is from the town of Banga. He is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Norberto grows crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Norberto has been engaged in his business for more than 15 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

Norberto joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Norberto is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Norberto from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement his family's income. 

About CEVI:
Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients, but also savings, insurance, and training, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

loans.name: Jonalyn

texts.en:
Jonalyn P. is from the village of Christine, District 1, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 26 years old. Jonalyn is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Jonalyn owns and operates a business making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals as well as engaging in the food processing business. Jonalyn has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Jonalyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jonalyn is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be Jonalyn's fourth loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Mrs. Sok Kha Sao Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sok Kha S. is a village bank president who has been selected by the other members. This village bank loan consists of eighteen people who are located in Preah Putth village in Kandal province.

She is a housewife who cooks delicious food for her family. Her husband, Mr. Sophan Chen, earns a living as an electronic repairman working out of his home.  Currently her husband has some problems because his electronic supplies are not sufficient to use. So to improve this business, Mrs. Sok Kha S. is asking for a loan to bU. some electronic supplies. With this livelihood, they support five children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory, and the others are attending a local public school.

loans.use: To buy some electronic supplies

She  requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build  a store for her charcoal.

loans.name: Sophorn's Group

texts.en: I. Preaek Cheang Prum-I Village I. Kandal Province, there is a group of four people who make up a group loan. Mrs. Sophorn I., 44 years old, is the group leader. She was selected by the other members, who will all use their share of the loan for different purposes. She is a fruit seller I. the local village. Her business is going well, and so she wants to expand it, and is seeking a loan to buy more fruit to resell. Her husband, Mr. Vanda OriE., is a farmer who rents a piece of land where he cultivates rice to support his family. She is the mother of four children. One of them is a government worker, another one is a laborer, and the others are attending a local public school.

loans.use: To buy more fruit to resell.

With the extra profits from her loan, Mary hopes to be able to build a shop.

loans.name: Mr. Saren Reach Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan is made up of eight people, who are all villagers in York Bat village in Kandal Province. Mr. Saren R. is a village bank president, selected by the other members, who will use their share of the loan for different purposes. He was born in 1967. He provides motorcycle transport to support his family, but he has a problem because his motorbike is too old to use. Therefore Mr. Saren R. is asking for a loan to buy a new motorbike to replace his old one. His wife, Mrs. Daney Loeng, is a housewife who makes delicious food for her family. Through these activities, the couple supports four children, one of whom is a seamstress in garment factory, while another is a construction worker, and the others are studying at a local public school.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike.

loans.name: Kasolo East Sebera Sarah Group

texts.en: Sarah S. is a thirty six year old hardworking business woman, She is married with three children who are in  school and she looks after three dependents who are also in school. Sarah has had a drug shop business for sixteen years. She  will use her loan to purchase a variety of drugs to meet her customers’ demands. She is trying very hard to stock as much as she can to improve her drug shop. Sarah's dream is to purchase a car.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of drugs to meet her customers’ needs.

loans.name: Slyvia

texts.en: Slyvia M. N. is 32 years old.  She runs Mama Cikui retail shop in Kiambu.  She sells foodstuffs and cooking gas in her shop. Slyvia started this business in 2004.  She joined the Ikinyana Mbere group of entrepreneurs to save  money.  She can get a loan from Faulu Kenya through the group.  Slyvia uses her weekly savings with the group to invest in her business.  She is requesting for a loan of Kes. 50, 000 to add stock of maize flour, rice and cooking gas.  She hopes to become financially stable in the future.

loans.use: To buy maize flour, rice and cooking gas

loans.name: Umut's Group

texts.en:
Umut K. is the leader of the group. She is 52 years old and a widow. She has raised a son and two daughters. Her son works as a mechanic and the daughters are married and live separately with their families. A year ago Umut's children suggested she open a kiosk and sell convenience goods. The profits from her business have allowed Umut  to purchase a vehicle for her son. Umut also breeds livestock and with money received from this  loan she wants to purchase some sheep and convenience goods to increase the turnover of her business. In the future she plans to expand the business and increase the number of livestock.

Mairamkul I. 63, is a widow. She has raised four daughters and a son. All the children are married and live separately with their families, except the son, who lives with Mairamkul. The son provides excavator services and his wife helps Mairamkul with her business. They take orders and sew traditional clothes. Mairamkul has applied for a loan because she needs money to purchase a variety of fabrics.

Zhursun U. 48, is the treasurer of the group. Her husband works as a taxi driver. They have two sons and three daughters. The older daughter is married and lives separately with her family. The second daughter works in Bishkek and the other children go to school. Three years ago Zhursun began to breed cattle. She also sells milk to make money.  Zhursun wants to get a loan to purchase some sheep for breeding.

Maksat T. is 24. Four years ago he got a loan and  with that money he bought a mini bus and began to provide transportation services. With the profit from his business it became possible for him to purchase a house. With money received from this loan Maksat plans to purchase building materials to start the construction of the kitchen.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young, ambitious and socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). Mol Bulak is the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the Mol Bulak Finance staff.

loans.use: To purchase some sheep for breeding

loans.name: Nakalama North Nangobi Sumini Group

texts.en: Sumini N. is a hardworking business woman of thirty-two years, married with seven children of whom five are in school. She also cares for two orphans who are in school. She has a restaurant business  which she has been running for over ten years. She will use the loan to purchase foodstuffs such as bananas, maize, beans, sugar, and  milk, and charcoal to meet her customers’ demands. Sumini's  dream is to purchase a plot of land.

loans.use: To purchase foodstuffs such as bananas, maize, beans, sugar and milk and charcoal, to meet her customers’ demands.

Mrs. Kakda S. is a village bank president, selected by the other members, who will all use their share of the loan for different purposes. She is a weaver who can earn some money to support herself and her famiL.. Since her business is going well she wants to expand it. To improve her business, Mrs. Kakda S. is asking for a loan to buy more thread to weave. She single and lives in a six-member household.

loans.use: To buy more thread.

loans.name: Nakalama North Harriet Namugose Group

texts.en: Harriet N. is a hardworking business woman of thirty-five years of age, single, with two dependents who are in school. She has been running a retail shop business for four years. She will use her loan to purchase retail items such as salt, soap and sugar for sale in order to expand her business. Harriet is a promising business woman whose dream is to improve her family's welfare.

loans.use: To purchase retail items such as salt, soap and sugar for sale to expand her business

loans.name: Sègodo

texts.fr: H. Sègodo est né le 14 Décembre 1981 et vit depuis deux ans au quartier Avotrou à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Sègodo n’est pas encore marié. Sègodo vit seul et assure seul ses différentes charges. Sègodo n’a pas été à l’école. C’est un brodeur qui a son atelier situé à Jéricho, à Cotonou. Parallèlement à cette activité, Sègodo vend des tissus bazins dans son atelier. Sègodo s’approvisionne à Lomé au Togo, et parfois à Douala au Cameroun. C’est la première fois que Sègodo sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un prêt, en vue de renforcer et d’élever le niveau de son activité, pour mieux satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Sègodo H. was born 14 December 1981, and for the past two years has been living in the Avotrou borough of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Sègodo is not yet married; he lives alone and takes care of his own expenses. Sègodo has not attended school. He is an embroiderer with a workshop located in the Jericho area of Cotonou. As a side business, he sells bazin clothing fabric in his workshop. He gets his supplies from Lomé in neighbouring Togo, and sometimes from Douala in Cameroun. This is the first time Sègodo is requesting a loan from ALIDé, to strengthen and raise the level of his business activity, and better satisfy customer demand.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy phonix thread for embroidery, and bazin clothing fabric

loans.name: Harrison

texts.en:
Harrison is a 47-year-old married man with four children, 4 to 18 years old.

Harrison was previously selling tomatoes to earn a living but now he operates a business called Alma Electricals where he sells electrical goods. He also does repair and maintenance of electronics and has been running the business for three years. He also supplies stationery to earn extra income. 

Harrison saves his money on weekly basis with a group in Faulu Kenya. In this group, the members guarantee each other’s loans. Harrison has requested a loan of Kes 40,000 to add to his stock of electrical goods.

loans.use: To add to his stock of electrical goods

loans.name: Rachelle

texts.fr: S. Rachelle est née le 22 Mars 1970 et vit depuis quinze ans environs au quartier Sènadé à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à BODEHOUSSE Casmir, un enseignant, Rachelle est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Rachelle vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants à Sènadé. Le couple se partage les différentes charges du foyer. Rachelle a arrêté l'école à l'université. Il y a environs huit ans que Rachelle a commencé la vente de produits divers (conserves de tomate et de sardine, riz, huile d'arachide, papiers hygiéniques, arachides grillés, etc.) à son domicile. Rachelle s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà bénéficié de trois prêts qui ont été tous bien remboursés. Rachelle désire augmenter le stock de ses produits et mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle ; raison pour laquelle Rachelle sollicite un quatrième prêt.
texts.en:
Rachelle S. was born 22 March 1970, and has been living about 15 years in the Sènadé borough of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Married to Casmir BODEHOUSSE, a teacher, Rachelle is the mother of three children, all attending (or having attended) school. She lives with her husband and children in Sènadé. The couple shares the various household expenses. Rachelle stopped attending school at university level. About eight years ago she began selling various products (canned tomatoes and sardines, rice, peanut oil, toilet paper, roasted peanuts, etc.) from her home. She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace. Rachelle is a former client of ALIDé, having already been granted three loans, all fully reimbursed. She wants to increase her stock supply and better respond to customer demand, which is why she is requesting a fourth loan.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy food products (rice, canned tomatoes and sardines, pasta, etc.), and peanut oil containers.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en: Peter is a 38-year-old married man with three children.  He has been doing welding for four years.  He also does farming to earn extra income for supporting his family.  Since he joined Faulu Kenya in a group called Nuru Investment, he has become very positive about business.  Therefore he puts a lot of effort into his business.  Being a member of the group, he has been guaranteed a loan of Kes. 20,000 by the members.  With the loan, he plans to buy scrap metal, files and flax.  He hopes to expand his business and open more businesses in the future.

loans.use: To buy scrap metal, files and flax

loans.name: Mrs. Chan Sim Thorn Village Bank Group

texts.en: This group of nineteen people, located in Chrouy Ampil-VB-I Village in Kandal Province, has selected Mrs. Chan Sim T. to be their village bank president. They make up a village bank loan, and will each use their share of the loan for different purposes, so that it can improve their businesses in the future. Mrs. Chan Sim T. was born in 1977. She is employed in a bread shop, and her husband is an electrician. Both of them earn a low salary, which they use to support their family. Their problem is that their house is too old to live in. Mrs. Chan Sim T. is asking for a loan to fix her old house. This couple does N. have any children, and they live in a two-member household.

loans.use: To fix her old house.

loans.name: Productive Women Group

texts.en:
Susie H., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Productive Women. She is 42 years old, married, and has four children who range from 9 to 24 years old. She was only able to attend school through eighth grade. She cares for two siblings and all of her children are attending school.

For 11 years, she has been selling rice, pepper, oil, salt, and onions at the Freeport Market in Monrovia, Liberia. She says customers get attracted to her business because she talks to them in a friendly manner. She plans to use her 15,000 LRD portion of this 66,000 LRD group loan to buy more rice, pepper, oil, salt, and onions. She describes herself as a quiet person. Her goal is to expand her business and to continue to support her children so that they can have a better future.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Augustine is inset at lower right because he was absent during the interview.

loans.use: To buy more rice, pepper, oil, salt, and onions.

loans.name: Pauline

texts.fr: E. Pauline est née le 27 Septembre 1979 et est mariée à AHOLOU Yeyi Théodore. Le couple a deux enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Il y a une douzaine d'année que Pauline s'est installée au quartier N'Vènamédé à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, où elle vit avec son mari et ses enfants. Pauline aide son mari à supporter les différentes charges de la famille. Pour y arriver, Pauline mène comme activité, la vente d'ustensiles de cuisine, mais également la vente de montres et de parfums à son domicile. Pauline achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Pauline exerce cette activité depuis une dizaine d'année. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu quatre crédits qui ont tous été bien remboursés. Face à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle, Pauline désire rehausser le niveau de son activité et mieux satisfaire sa clientèle. C'est pourquoi Pauline sollicite l'appui financier de ALIDé, pour une cinquième fois.
texts.en:
Pauline E. was born 27 September 1979, and is married to Yeyi Théodore AHOLOU. The couple has two children, both attending (or having attended) school. About 12 years ago Pauline settled in the N'Vènamédé borough of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, where she lives with her husband and children. She helps her husband deal with various family expenses. To make ends meet, Pauline has been running a business selling kitchen utensils - but also watches and perfume - from her home. She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace. She has been performing this activity for the past ten years. She is a former client of ALIDé, having already been granted four loans, all fully reimbursed. Facing increasing customer demands, Pauline wants to raise the level of her business activity and improve customer satisfaction. This is why she is requesting the financial support of ALIDé, for the fifth time.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy kitchen utensils and watches.

loans.name: Mrs. Sophan Deoum Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan has twenty-one people who are all villagers in Chrouy Ampil village in Kandal province.

Mrs. Sophan D. is the village bank president as selected by the other members who will each use their portion of the loan for different purposes. She is 30 years-old and owns a general store at her home. Since her business is going well she wants to expand. In order, to improve her business, Mrs. Sophan D. is asking for a loan to buy more groceries to resell. Her husband, Mr. Chantha Korng, is a seamstress in a garment factoR.. Through these activities, they support two children who are studying in local public school.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to resell.

loans.name: God Is In Control Group

texts.en:
Esther N., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called "God Is In Control". She is 43 years-old, unmarried and has three children who range from 16 to 28 years old. She was only able to attend school through 12th grade. She also cares for two siblings and all of her children are attending school. 

For nine years, she has been selling used clothes at the Ma-Juah Market in Monrovia, Liberia.  She says customers are attracted to her business because she talks to them in a friendly manner.

She plans to use her 20,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 44,000 Liberian Dollar group loan to buy more bags of used clothes. She describes herself as a determined woman.
 
Her goal is to expand her business and to continue to support her children so that they can have a better future.

loans.use: To buy more bags of used clothes.

loans.name: Fredrick

texts.en:
Fredrick is a 33-year-old metal fabricator who does manufacturing, welding, and tinsmithing for wholesalers in his region.  He has been in this business for 9 years and has 5 employees.  Fredrick is married and has 3 children, 1 boy and 2 girls, from 7 months to 8 years old. 

The primary business challenges he faces are the unreliable power supply and the fact that high quality raw materials are not readily available.  In addition to his metal shop, Fredrick also sells spare parts for bicycles and motorcycles at a local market.  Before owning the metal shop, he operated a bicycle transport service (“boda boda”). 

Fredrick plans to use the 20,000 KES loan to purchase materials for welding and spare parts for bicycles.  

In the future, he hopes to earn enough money to provide a quality education for his children.  In 5 years, he dreams of purchasing a plot of land for commercial and residential purposes.

Fredrick describes himself as honest, kind, and humble.

loans.use: To purchase materials for welding and spare parts for bicycles

loans.name: Loice

texts.en:
Loice is a 30-year-old shoe seller.  She sells shoes to local customers at a marketplace along a busy road that leads to Nairobi.  She has been in this business for 5 years.  Loice is married and has 3 children, 2 boys and 1 girl, from 4 to 14 years old.  Before selling shoes on her own, she worked in a retail shop.

Loice plans to use the 20,000 KES loan to purchase additional shoe inventory for resale.  In the future, she hopes to supply uniforms to schools and government agencies.

Loice describes herself as a loving and caring mother.

loans.use: To purchase additional shoe inventory for resale

loans.name: Faith And Trust Group

texts.en:
Rebecca B., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called "Faith And Trust". She is 51 years-old and married with four children who range from 15 to 32 years old. She holds a diploma in secretarial science. She also cares for two siblings. 

For three years, she has been selling used clothes at the Vai Town Market, Monrovia, Liberia.

She plans to use her 7,500 Liberian Dollar portion of this 37,500 Liberian Dollar group loan to buy more bags of used clothes. 

Her goal is to improve her business, make more profit, buy land and build a house so that her children can have a better future.

loans.use: To buy bags of used clothes.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: books, stationerery items, and renovations for a nursery school

loans.name: Godfrey

texts.en:
Godfrey is a 34-year-old “matatu” owner.  "Matatus" are privately owned, 14-passenger vans used extensively throughout Kenya for public transportation. They drive a specific route each day to pick up and drop off pay-as-you-go passengers along the way.  He has been in this business for 4 years and has 4 employees.  Godfrey is married and has 2 sons, 3 and 6 years old. 

The primary business challenges he faces are vehicle breakdowns, the high cost of spare parts, and police harassment.  In addition to his "matatu" business, Godfrey also gets income from a tailoring business.  Before being a "matatu" owner, he was a "matatu" driver.

Godfrey plans to use the 40,000 KES loan to upgrade his "matatu" (14-passenger minivan) with new paint and new seats.  He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 KES.

In the future, Godfrey hopes to buy a new vehicle.  In 5 years, he dreams of having higher income, owning land, and building a home.

Godfrey describes himself as aggressive in business and faithful.

loans.use: To upgrade his "matatu" (14 passenger minivan) with new paint and new seats

loans.name: Geoffrey

texts.en:
Geoffrey, a 23-year-old married father of a five-year-old boy and a 7-month-old girl, sells CDs, DVDs, and audio tapes in a very busy marketplace that is full of travelers. In this business for three years, the primary business challenge he faces is unpredictable weather, as rain drives away his customers. He was a laborer at a tea factory previously.

Geoffrey plans to use the 20,000 KES loan to purchase blank CDs and DVDs for media production, and in the future hopes to instill in his family a culture of entrepreneurship. Describing describes himself as hardworking and courageous, he dreams of opening a recording studio in 5 years.

loans.use: To purchase blank CDs and DVDs for media production

loans.name: Nakalama C East Mutesi Jamawa Group

texts.en:
M. Jamawa is a hardworking business woman. She is fifty years old and married with five children and three dependents (siblings), two of whom are going to school.

She has been running a tailoring business for over six years. She is using this loan to purchase materials for designing clothes to sell.

She is a determined business woman whose dreams are to prosper, educate her kids, and improve the welfare of her family.

loans.use: To purchase materials for designing clothes to sell

loans.name: Maurice

texts.en:
Maurice is 34 years old and married with two children. Since 1998, he has been running a cafeteria where he has employed two people.

Maurice belongs to a group called Muninga Victory in Faulu Kenya where he has learned how to save his money. He uses his savings to invest in his business. Maurice has been guaranteed a loan of Kes. 30,000 by the group members. He plans to use this money to expand the business and pay for his exams. He hopes to build his own house in the future.

loans.use: To expand the business and pay for his exams

loans.name: Geoffrey

texts.en:
Geoffrey is a 24-year-old married man with one child.  He sells household goods while his wife is a farmer.  He started this business after finishing his high school studies.  

He is an active member of Ngumbau group in Faulu, Kenya, whose members guarantee each other's loan.  He previously took out a loan of Kes. 20,000 from Faulu Kenya and successfully repaid it.  He has requested a new loan of Kes. 30,000.  With this loan he plans to buy basins, buckets and soap to sell. 

In the future, he hopes to own a car and a piece of land, and to provide quality education for his child.

loans.use: To buy basins, buckets and soaps

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Quetonu Group

texts.en:
Grace M., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Quetonu.  She is 35 years-old, unmarried and has one child who is eight years old. She is a university graduate. She cares for two siblings. 

For six years, she has been selling used clothes at the Via Town Market, Monrovia, Liberia.

She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollar group loan to buy more bags of used clothes. 

Her goal is to improve her business and continue to support her child for a better future.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Frances is inset in the lower right because she was absent during the interview.

loans.use: To buy more bags of used clothes.

loans.name: Lemu Group

texts.en:
Mary F., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called "Lemu". She is 44 years-old, married and has six children who range from one to 24 years old. She did not attend school due to poverty. She also cares for three siblings. All of her children are in school. 

For five years, she has been selling charcoal at the ELWA Market on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia. She says customers are attracted to her business because she sells good charcoal.

She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollar group loan to buy more bags of charcoal. She describes herself as a very easy-going person.

Her dream is to improve her business and be able to assist other family members.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Graace

texts.en:
Graace is a 49-year-old lady who is married and has ten children.  Her children go to school.  

Graace has been operating a retail shop for five years.  She started this business because her salary could not support her big family.  She is in a group of ladies who are entrepreneurs called Furaha Ladies in Faulu, Kenya.  She joined this group with an aim of sharing business ideas, saving money and being guaranteed a loan by the group members.  She is requesting a loan of Kes. 30,000 from Faulu Kenya.  She wants to use this money to buy sodas, sugar, cooking fat and cakes.

loans.use: To buy sodas, sugar, cooking fat and cakes

loans.name: Anne-Marie

texts.fr: Née en 1964 au Bénin, D. Anne-Marie est mariée à HOUNGBEME Simon et est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Anne-Marie vit avec sa famille au quartier Senadé à Cotonou capital économique du Bénin, depuis dix ans. Anne-Marie vient en aide à son mari et assure avec lui les différentes charges de la famille. Anne-Marie n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Il y a près de quinze ans que Anne-Marie achète des cartons de pommes fruits auprès des grossistes importateurs du Bénin  pour revendre en détails à Sèmè non loin de la frontière nigériane. Face à la demande de plus en plus existante de sa clientèle, Anne-Marie  voudrait augmenter son stock de produits afin de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle. C’est ce qui l’amène à solliciter pour la quatrième fois, un crédit auprès de ALIDé après que les trois derniers aient été remboursés dans de meilleures conditions. Anne-Marie ambitionne plus tard acquérir une parcelle pour y vivre avec sa famille.
texts.en:
Born in 1964 in Benin, Anne-Marie D. is married to Simon HOUNGBEME and is the mother of three children, all attending (or having attended) school. For the past ten years she has lived with her family in the Senadé borough of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She helps her husband and they jointly deal with different family expenses. Anne-Marie has not attended school. About 15 years ago she started buying crates of apples from Benin’s wholesale importers, to resell them retail in Sèmè, not far from the Nigerian border. Facing increasing demands from her customers, she would like to increase her stock of supplies to increase customer satisfaction. This is why she is now requesting a fourth loan from ALIDé, having fully repaid the three preceding ones. Anne-Marie has the ambition of buying a plot of land in the future, to live there with her family.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy apples

loans.name: In God We Trust Group

texts.en:
Joshua S., shown holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called In God We Trust. A 25-year-old single father of a five-month-old child, Joshua was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to financial difficulties.

For 2 years, he has been molding and selling cement blocks for construction in Thinkers Village outside of Monrovia, Liberia and plans to use his 8,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 40,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more bags of cement. Joshua's dream is to expand his business, build a shop and leave the block-molding business.

loans.use: To buy more bags of cement.

loans.name: Biasha

texts.en:
Sarah used to be a coconut seller, but 15 years ago she opened her grocery shop. She also sells firewood as an alternative source of income. From her shop, she primarily sells her goods to her neighbors, and she says the business is doing very well. She has requested this loan to restock her shop.

Sarah has a full house, with 8 children (evenly split between boys and girls, and all in school) in addition to herself and her husband, who works as a watchman.

She currently owns her house (with no electricity or piped water), and her plan for the future is to make enough to build a rental house that she can use as a second source of income.

loans.use: To buy maize flour, fish, cooking oil, and wheat flour

loans.name: Wissam

texts.en:
Wissam is a 38-year-old married man from Lebanon. He lives with his wife and two small children (ages 6 months and 3 and a half years). He has over 13 years of experience running a clothing shop. He sells clothes for women and children. He says that he is proud of the high quality of his work. He believes his honesty and experience working in the sales field since he was young have helped distinguish him. His main customers are friends and neighbors. 

He is requesting a loan of US$ 1500 from Kiva partner, A. Majmoua. He plans to purchase new merchandise for his store. In the future, he would like to make more wholesale purchases to reduce costs and increase his profits. This will be his first loan from A. Majmoua.

loans.use: To purchase new merchandise for his store.

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema has been selling her neighbors cooked food  like chapati (flat bread), beans and rice for three years. She is a married woman with 3 boys and three girls, who attend school. With the KShs. 20,000, Rehema wants to purchase more wheat flour and cooking oil. She also plants food crops in her farm. 
	
Her greatest challenge is experiencing low sales. She owns a home which does not have water or electricity. She says school fees are her great expenses. She hopes to someday open a stall since she currently takes food to shop owners.

She joined Yehu so as to access loans and expand her business and eventually support her family more comfortably.

loans.use: To buy wheat flour and cooking oil

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en:
Hassan is a 60-year-old borrower from Lebanon. He has 25 years of experience as a butcher. He is married and has one son who is 23 years old. He is proud of the high quality of products he sells. He sells different varieties of meat and chicken. He believes that his honesty with customers has been important to his success. He notes that the competition in his locA. area has presented some challenges to his work.  His main customers are friends and neighbors.

He is requesting a loan of US$ 1500 from Kiva partner, A. Majmoua. He plans to purchase more cows with this loan. He hopes to continue to improve his work in the coming year. This will be his first loan from A. Majmoua.

loans.use: To purchase more cows to slaughter

loans.name: Kabungo Women's Group, Ntungamo

texts.en:
As they say, hard work pays, and a very determined T. Pelly has gained from the fruits of her hard work. Having started up her hotel and lodging enterprise twelve years ago in Omungyenyi, Ntungamo, a common stopover for long-route drivers from Rwanda, Pelly has no regrets.

Due to Pelly’s good management and esteemed customer care, her business has maintained customers for a long time, thus creating the hotel a good market. With this loan, Pelly wants to put in place a pool table as it is a favorite game for many. She will also use the loan to buy foodstuffs for the hotel. This will enable her to earn more profit and enable her to cater for the requirements of her four fatherless children as she was widowed at a tender age.

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs and a pool table for her hotel

loans.name: Khaled

texts.en:
Khaled is a 51-year-old borrower from Lebanon. He is married and has two sons ages 18 and 20. He has more than 15 years of experience as a mechanic. He is proud of his extensive experience and honest work. He is able to serve a diverse range of clients in his business. He notes that he has faced some challenges in securing sufficient financing for his business. 

He is requesting a loan of US$ 1500 from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua. He plans to invest in new tools for his work. He hopes to further expand and enhance his work in the future. This will be his second loan from Al Majmoua.

loans.use: To invest in new tools for his work

loans.name: Nezikokoolima Women's Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
A decade running a competitive and cutthroat business is no walk in the park, as 49-year-old N. Yeko would attest. This married mother of five has had to make the best out of hard bargains that have plagued her business, to get herself on a stable footing.

In Kigenda, Lugazi, where Yeko runs her businesses selling bananas and passion fruit, she has had to summon up a sense of resilience and determination to establish for herself a dependable niche. On weekly profits totaling up to 40,000 shillings, her business has made steady progress. As a testimony to this, she has managed to educate all five of her children. She was into a coffee-selling business before she ventured into her current enterprise.

With this loan, Yeko wants to revamp and expand her business through the purchase of more bags of bananas and passion fruit that she will later sell to her increasing clientele.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of bananas and passion fruit to sell

loans.name: Sharlet

texts.en:
Sharlet is a mother of five, four girls and one boy.  Two of her children are adults. 

She has been working as a tailor for one year, but previously worked in a factory making clothes.  She sells khangas (traditional cotton garments), and tailors dresses for her clients.  Sharlet's husband is in the hotel business, but they also have a small grocery stall where they sell vegetables for some additional income.  

Sharlet's main business challenge is that sometimes she gets few clients.  Her goal is to one day own her own stall (currently she rents).  She originally joined Yehu Microfinance because she saw other members in her community benefiting from the loans they were receiving, and she thought she might be able to expand her business as well.

loans.use: To buy cloth for her garment-making

loans.name: Adjouavi

texts.fr: Née en 1973 au Bénin, G. Adjouavi  est mariée à DJOSSOU Vissin. Le couple a deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Il y a près de quinze ans que Adjouavi s’est installée avec son mari au quartier Hindé à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Le couple se partage les différentes charges familiales. Adjouavi n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Adjouavi  prépare de la bouillie (faite à base de d'amidon de maïs et du sucre) qu'elle vend depuis douze ans dans son quartier à Hindé. Adjouavi fait ses provisions à Cotonou. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu quatre prêts qui ont tous été bien remboursés. Adjouavi désire augmenter le volume de ses ventes et accroître sa clientèle ; raison pour laquelle Adjouavi sollicite l’aide financier de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born in 1973 in Benin, Adjouavi G. is married to Vissin DJOSSOU. The couple has two children, both at school. It is almost 15 years now since Adjouavi settled down with her husband in the Hindé district of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. The couple shares the various family expenses. Adjouavi did not go to school. She makes "bouillie" (a type of gruel made from corn starch and sugar) which she has been selling for 12 years in the Hindé district. She gets her supplies in Cotonou. She is an old customer of ALIDé, having already had four loans; all these loans have been repaid on time. Adjouavi wants to increase her sales volume and her customer base; for this reason she is seeking financial help from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of bags of corn and sugar

loans.name: Silpah

texts.en:
Silpah is a married woman with two children, one girl and one boy; one attends school and the other is still too young for school. With the Kshs. 40,000 loan, she hopes to purchase bales of cloth for her cloth-selling business. She has been in the business for 3 years and hopes to someday sell imported clothes. She has no other source of income. 

She decided to work with Yehu because she wanted to expand her business and uplift her family's living standards. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees, as life in the city is of higher standards compared to life at the farm. She lives in a rental house with electricity but no piped water.

loans.use: To buy bales of cloth

loans.name: Nasser

texts.en:
Nasser is a 25-year-old single man from Lebanon. He has five years of experience working in the services industry. He specializes in polishing tiles. This type of profession is common throughout Lebanon. He is very proud of his work experience. He is able to serve different types of clients through his work. He notes that competition and lack of sufficient capitA. have been challenges to his work. 

He is requesting a loan of US$ 1500 from Kiva partner, A. Majmoua. He plans to invest in a new tile polishing machine. He hopes to continue to grow and enhance his business in the coming year. This will be his first loan from A. Majmoua.

loans.use: To invest in a new tile polishing machine

loans.name: Grâce

texts.fr: L. Grâce est née en 1980 et est marié à HOUNDETON Coovi. Grâce est mère d’un seul enfant qui est scolarisé. Le couple vit avec leur enfant au quartier Fidjrossè à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, depuis quinze ans. Grâce vient en aide à son mari et assure avec lui les différentes charges de la famille. Grâce n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Il y a près de sept ans que Grâce vend de façon ambulante des tissus. De façon secondaire, Grâce vend également des chaussures. C’est à Dantokpa, grand marché du Bénin que Grâce achète ses produits. Grâce a déjà eu un concours financier auprès de ALIDé avec un bon remboursement. Face à la demande de plus en plus importante de sa clientèle, Grâce voudrait augmenter son stock de produits afin de mieux faire face aux exigences de sa clientèle. C’est ce qui l’amène à solliciter pour la deuxième fois, un  nouveau crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Grâce L. was born in 1980 and is married to Coovi HOUNDETON. Grâce is mother to one child who is at school. For the past 15 years the couple have lived together with their child in the Fidjrossè district of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Grâce supports her husband and helps him to cover the various household expenses. She did not go to school. For almost seven years she has been selling fabrics on a door-to-door basis. As a secondary activity she also sells shoes. Grâce buys her products at Dantokpa, the large market in Benin. She would like to increase her stock in order to meet client demand better. It is for this reason that she is requesting a second loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fabric

loans.name: Anastasie

texts.fr: H. Anastasie est née en 1970 au Bénin. Anastasie est mariée à De CAMPOS Valerien, un militaire. Le couple a trois enfants, tous scolarisés. La famille vit à Fidjrossè un quartier de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, depuis une dizaine d’année. Anastasie subvient avec son mari aux différents besoins de la famille. Anastasie n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Pour assurer ses besoins, Anastasie mène comme activité principale la vente de tissus, de chaussures, et comme activité secondaire la vente de fournitures scolaires (cahiers, stylos, etc.). Anastasie s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et aussi à Lomé au Togo. Anastasie exerce cette activité depuis neuf ans, dans une boutique de son quartier. Anastasie a déjà bénéficié d’un crédit auprès de ALIDé, crédit qui a été bien remboursé. Anastasie sollicite un deuxième prêt pour augmenter son stock de produits, ce qui lui permettra d’accroître son chiffre d’affaire.
texts.en:
Anastasie H. was born in 1970 in Benin. She is married to Valerien De CAMPOS, a soldier. The couple has three children, all at school. The family has been living in the Fidjrossè district of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, for around ten years. Anastasie supports her husband in providing the various needs of the family. She did not go to school. In order to cover her needs, Anastasie has a primary activity selling fabric and shoes, and she has a secondary activity selling school materials (exercise books, pens etc.). She gets her supplies at Dantokpa, Benin's international market, and also in Lomé, Togo. Anastasie has been carrying out this activity for nine years in a shop in her neighborhood. She has already had one loan from ALIDé, which she repaid on time. She is requesting a second loan to increase her stock, which will in turn allow her to increase her turnover.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fabric, shoes and exercise books

loans.name: Kweterana Women's Group, Ntungamo

texts.en:
This friendly and very hardworking lady, K. Edisa, has been running a fish-catching and selling business for two years. She transports the fish from Ntungamo to Kampala city, earning her a reasonable profit of 400,000 Ugandan shillings monthly.

Edisa’s main challenge has been having a small stock due to the hindrances of low capital input into her business. This loan will help her buy fishing nets and increase her stock to match her customers’ demand.

Edisa thinks of commercializing her business and expanding it which will enable her to earn more revenue and be able to pay school fees for her four children and other dependents, and cater for other family needs.

loans.use: To buy fishing nets and increase her stock of fish

loans.name: Bertille

texts.fr: Née le 05 Novembre 1979 au Benin, A. Bertille est une veuve. Bertille est mère de trois enfants tous scolarisés, et a un autre enfant à sa charge. Bertille vit ensemble avec ses enfants au quartier Fidjrossè à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Bertille a fait les cours primaires. Bertille exerce comme activité depuis neuf ans environs la vente de tissus et de tenues. De façon secondaire, Bertille vend des ustensiles de cuisine, et des cartes de recharges téléphoniques ; ce qui lui permet de subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants. Bertille s’approvisionne au grand marché international du Bénin Dantokpa, et à Lomé (au Togo), un pays voisin du Bénin. Bertille vend également ses produits à Dantokpa. Bertille a déjà bénéficié d’un premier prêt auprès de ALIDé avec un bon remboursement et vient solliciter un second prêt, pour renforcer son activité. Bertille ambitionne devenir grossiste dans la vente de ses produits.
texts.en:
Born 5 November 1979 in Benin, Bertille A. is a widow. She is the mother of three children, all attending (or having attended) school, and takes care of another child. Bertille lives with her children in the Fidjrossé borough of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Bertille attended primary school. For the past nine years she has been running a business selling clothing fabric and ready-made clothes. As a side business, she also sells kitchen utensils, and phone cards for mobiles, which enables her to meet her children’s needs. She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace, and from Lomé, in neighbouring Togo. She also sells her products in Dantokpa. Bertille has already been granted one loan from ALIDé, which was duly reimbursed. She is now requesting a second loan to bolster her business. She has the ambition of becoming a wholesaler for the products she sells.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy clothing fabric and ready-made clothes

loans.name: Colette

texts.fr: Née en 1959 au Bénin, A. Colette est mariée à GBEHOU Joseph un conducteur. Le couple a deux enfants à charge. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés. Colette vit depuis douze ans environs au quartier Fidjrossè à Cotonou capitale économique du Benin, avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple se partage ensemble les différentes charges familiales. Colette n’a pas fréquenté l’école mais a appris la couture. Maitresse couturière, Colette mène comme activité secondaire la vente de produits de la mercerie depuis huit ans environs dans son atelier de couture. Colette achète ses produits au grand marché international du Bénin Dantokpa. C’est la deuxième fois que Colette sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un prêt, pour faire évoluer son activité ce qui lui permettra de mieux faire face aux exigences de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Born in 1959 in Benin, Colette A. is married to Joseph GBEHOU. The couple have two children under their care, both having attended school. For the past ten years Colette has been living with her husband and children in the Fidjrossé borough of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. The couple shares the handling of family expenses. Coleet has not attended school herself, but learned sewing instead. An accomplished seamstress, she has also been running a side business for the past eight years, selling haberdashery items in her sewing workshop. Colette buys her products at Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace. This is the second time Colette is requesting a loan from ALIDé, to make her business evolve and become better suited to meet customer demands.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy haberdashery items

loans.name: Luz Cerito (Grupos 1, 2) Group

texts.en:
C. is the coordinator of her group Lucerito (Bright Star), and her story is representative both of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients generally, many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti. Her group is located in Los Arcarizos, a dusty industrial area north of the capital where free trade zones are common and running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home there in a simple structure with her long-term partner and their two children.

C. is excited to be taking her third loan with Esperanza, after having fully repaid her previous loans and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her jewelry and general supplies store and will put the additional profits towards the purchase of a small plot of land, with the hope of constructing a house on it sometime in the future. C. thanks all of you for your support.

loans.use: To buy jewelry, cleaning products and other supplies for sale

loans.name: Mujeres De Debora 1,2 Group

texts.en:
Maria is the coordinator of her group Mujeres de Debora (Debora's Women), and her story is representative both of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in Puerto Plata, an area whose economy is dependent on tourism and where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home there in a simple structure with her long-term partner and three children.

Maria is excited to be taking her fifth loan with Esperanza after having fully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her ambulatory business selling underwear by purchasing bras, undershirts and underwear to sell. She will use the profits to save toward building a location for her business. She thanks all of you for your support.

loans.use: Panties, brassieres and undershirts to sell

loans.name: Bapapoble Group

texts.en:
Cecelia N., shown holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Bapapoble. A 39-year-old married mother of five children who range from 3 to 17 years old, she was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to poverty. She also cares for three siblings. All of her children are attending school.

For 10 years, Cecelia has been selling dried fish in West Point Market in Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 12,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 54,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more dried fish. Describing herself as a good woman with good character, Cecelia hopes to expand her business and educate her children so that they can have a better future.

loans.use: To buy more dried fish.

loans.name: Rosette

texts.fr: B. Rosette est née en 1979 au Bénin. Mariée à DOHOUNGO Jean un agent au Port Autonome de Cotonou, Rosette est mère de deux enfants tous scolarisés. La famille vit depuis dix ans au quartier Fidjrossè à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Rosette vient en aide à son mari et assure avec lui les différentes charges de la famille. Rosette n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Il y a près de sept ans que Rosette vend des tissus par le système de distribution. C’est à Dantokpa grand marché du Bénin, que Rosette achète ses produits. Après avoir bénéficié d’un premier prêt auprès de ALIDé avec un remboursement sans difficulté, Rosette sollicite un second prêt pour augmenter son stock de produits afin de satisfaire les besoins de sa clientèle toujours existants.
texts.en:
Rosette B. was born in 1979 in Benin. Married to Jean DOHOUNGO, an agent at the Autonomous Port of Cotonou, Rosette is the mother of two children, both attending (or having attended) school. The family settled ten years ago in the Fidjrossé borough of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Rosette helps her husband deal with the various family expenses. Rosette has not attended school herself. For the past seven years she has been selling clothing fabric through the distribution system. She buys her products in Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace. Having been granted a first loan from ALIDé, which was reimbursed without problems, Rosette is now requesting a second loan to increase her stock supply and satisfy the constant needs of her customers.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy lengths of clothing fabric

loans.name: Mujeres Luchando Por El Progreso 3 Group

texts.en:
Marcelina is the coordinator of her group Luchando Por El Progreso (Fighting for Progress), and her story is representative both of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the urban slums surrounding Santiago, an area known for its tobacco production, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home there in a simple rented structure with her long-term partner and three children.

Marcelina is excited to be taking her first loan with Esperanza because she believes that the facilities offered by Esperanza will help her move forward. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business of selling a variety of goods including shoes, sheets and clothes by purchasing more merchandise. She will use the profits to purchase a freezer for her home which will improve her quality of life. Marcelina's long-term dream is to save towards owning her home. She thanks all of you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase shoes, sheets and clothing to sell

loans.name: Step By Step Group, Mukono

texts.en:
38-year-old N. Madrine has, for the last fourteen years, been going out of her way to obtain a firm footing in a competitive farming business in Kitega in Mukono. She mostly grows and sells mushrooms and, if it was not for her hard work, she would almost be courting failure after fourteen years. Her sense of determination meant she had to embrace an “all hands to the plough” approach to come to grips with the ominous odds that presented themselves in her mushroom farming business.

Madrine is at a point in her business where her resilience and experience are, to all intents and purposes, winning. With profits from her business, she has been able to shoulder all her family responsibilities. Every month her business generates her profits to the tune of 200,000 shillings. She also ekes out profits from rental apartments she constructed with her husband.

With this loan, Madrine is looking at buying more mushroom seedlings.

loans.use: To purchase more mushroom seedlings

loans.name: Bakusekamajja Development Group, Mukono

texts.en:
The fishmonger business has mostly been the preserve of men for quite a long time. For a woman, therefore, to bear a hand in such an undertaking in Busembatya, Mukono, was not only remarkable but also unconventional.

46-year-old N. Prossy was undeterred, however. She wanted to obtain a footing in this business regardless of ingrained societal beliefs. Approaching her late 30’s, she knew she had to set her wits to work to bring food to her family’s table. Her seven children had no support since their dad was deceased.

With enough courage and conviction, Prossy started off her business eighteen years ago. Her persistence and “never quit” attitude have ultimately been her invaluable stocks in trade. She makes approximately 200,000 shillings a month and, with this loan, she is aiming to revamp her fish-sales business.

loans.use: To purchase more fish and to revamp her stalls

loans.name: Zindzy

texts.en:
Zindzy has been running her bar for 8 years.  One month ago, however, she opened a small cafe / food stall as well, where she sells meat, chapatis (Kenyan flat-breads), and 'ugali'.  She cites competition and, from time to time, a lack of customers as her main business challenges.  She has high aspirations for her two businesses.  She'd like to expand her bar so that it can run at night as well, and she hopes to build another shop for her cafe.  

Zindzy's husband is a butcher, and together they have three children -- one girl (14) and two boys (3 and 14).  They have some additional income from a rental house they own.  Zindzy's own house has electricity but no piped water, and she says her largest expenses are school fees, medical expenses, and food.

loans.use: To buy beer for her bar

loans.name: Bulamu Bwoka Development Group, Mukono

texts.en:
Twenty years is the time widowed N. Fazira has spent in her food and charcoal selling business in Kavule, Mukono. Bent upon succeeding in everything she does, she has gone out of her way to get herself firmly rooted in this business.

Fazira’s long-haul experience has played into her hands. Knowing that the odds are not in her favor without a man, she has worked vigorously and hard to provide for her six children. Fortunately all of them are now in school.

With this loan, Fazira wants to buy more bags of basic foods and charcoal that she envisages she will, in turn, sell to her increasing clientele.

loans.use: To purchase basic foods like maize flour and beans to sell

loans.name: Grupo Unido 1 Group

texts.en:
Rafael is the coordinator of his group, Grupo Unido (United Group), and his story is representative of his group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients generally (many of whom recently emigrated to the Dominican Republic from Haiti). His group is located in the port town of Puerto Plata on the north coast, where the economy is dependent on tourism and where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. He makes his home here in a simple structure with his wife and three children.
Rafael is excited to be taking his first loan with Kiva partner, Esperanza, and is excited to invest in his business. He plans to use this loan to invest in his business running a small food market by purchasing 100lbs of chicken, 1kg of turkey and 0.5kg of yuca (cassava). He will use the profits to invest in completing construction of his home. He thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy 100lbs of chicken, 1kg of turkey and 0.5kg of yuca

loans.name: Nice Development Group, Mukono

texts.en:
