35-year-old O. Grace, a delightfully approachable mother of six children, has been plying her fresh foods business in Namuyenje, Mukono, for the last nine years. Notwithstanding the financial challenges and the modest profits accruing to her business, she has invariably made the avoidance of risk her first priority. Her “never beat a retreat” attitude has been her stock in trade and it seems she will continue to grow her business as a result of that attribute.

Grace’s profit margins have been mounting up and, at present, she makes weekly profits totaling up to 50,000 shillings. This is paltry but she is still optimistic that her business’s better days are in the offing.

loans.use: To purchase more fresh foods like tomatoes, avocadoes and beans to sell

loans.name: Visa Business People Group

texts.en:
James A., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Visa Business People. He is 37 years old, single, and has one child. He also cares for three siblings. James was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to financial difficulties.
For the past four years, James has been selling creme, soap, hair grease, perfume etc. in West Point Market, Monrovia, Liberia. He plans to use his 6,000 LRD portion of this 30,000 LRD group loan to buy more creme, soap, hair grease, perfume etc. His dream is to expand his business.

loans.use: To buy more creme, soap, hair grease, perfume etc.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy seedlings and to pay for labor on her livestock farm and plantation

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more dried meat

loans.name: Ana

texts.en:
Ana, 67, is an individual loan client with Kiva partner, Esperanza, and her story is representative of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients generally (many of whom recently emigrated to the Dominican Republic from Haiti). She is located in Puerto Plata, a port town on the north coast, where the economy is reliant on tourism and where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure.
Ana is excited to be taking her fourth loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling used clothing by purchasing four large packets of used clothes that come from places like the Salvation Army in the USA. She will use the profits to invest in reconstructing her home and meeting her basic needs. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To purchase four large packets of used clothing for resale

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more gallons of oil and bags of rice

loans.name: Constance

texts.en:
Constance is a married women with five children, 3 girls and 2 boys. They all go to school. She has been in her business for the past 12 years. Her previous occupation was selling vegetables. Her other sources of incomes are the grocery, mobile charging, and she also owns rental houses. She sells her products to neighbours.

Constance faces the challenges of high competition since many people have ventured into the same business. Her aspiration is to build a small well to get more water. She decided to join Yehu after obtaining business training skills offered by the Yehu staff to prospective clients. Constance has electricity and piped water in her house. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees.

loans.use: To buy a water tank

loans.name: Unidas Para Triunfar 1,2 Group

texts.en:
Benita is the coordinator of her group Unidas Para Triunfar (United to Triumph). Her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the Dominican Republic from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the urban slums surrounding Santiago, an area known for its tobacco production, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long-term partner and their two children.

Benita is excited to be taking her second loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling clothes. She will purchase large packets of used clothing that come from places like the Salvation Army in the United States. She will use the profits to invest in finishing her home. Her dream is to one day be able to travel the world with her family. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: Used clothing sales

loans.name: Mujeres Hacia El Progreso Grupo 1 Group

texts.en:
E. is the coordinator of her group Mujeres hacia el progreso (Women Towards Progress). Her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients generally, many of whom recently emigrated to the Dominican Republic from Haiti. Her group is located in Samana, a lush rugged peninsula with a nascent tourism industry, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here as a single mother (she has three children), in a simple structure which doubles as her bakery.

E. is excited to be taking her third loan with Esperanza, after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her bread-making business. She intends to buy a mixing and kneading machine for her home-based bakery and to make structural improvements to the building by installing a cement ceiling. She will use the profits to purchase school supplies for her children, and hopes to save some money for her children's future. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy machinery for a small bakery

loans.name: Mujeres Triunfadores 3 Group

texts.en:
Felicia is the coordinator of her group Mujeres Triunfadores (Triumphant Women). Her story is representative of her group and generally of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients, many of whom recently emigrated to the Dominican Republic from Haiti. Her group is located in Puerto Plata, a port town on the North Coast with an economy dominated by tourism, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long-term partner and two children.

Felicia is excited to be taking her second loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling shoes and clothing by purchasing a dozen pairs of shoes and a half dozen blouses to sell in her neighborhood. She will use the profits to invest in her home by changing the walls from wood to cement block, an important improvement in the termite-infested and hurricane-prone Dominican Republic. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To purchase blouses and shoes to sell

loans.name: Juana Maria

texts.es:
La señora Juana Maria R. es madre soltera y tiene bajo su responsabilidad a tres hijos de mediana edad, ha quines les quiere dar los estudios necesario para un buen futuro.
Solicita un préstamo para poder pagar las necesidades de la escuela de sus niños, ya que el están exigiendo que pagar  las colegiatura. El problema es que no cuenta con el dinero necesario para liquidar este compromiso escolar.
Planea pagar el crédito con una parte el ingreso que obtiene de sus ventas de productos de belleza por catalogó.
texts.en:
Juana is a single mother and has three school-aged children to support. She wants to provide a good education for them so that they can have a brighter future and is asking for this loan in order to be able to pay for her children’s schooling needs. Their tuition is due and she does not have the money. She plans to repay this loan from the income she generates from her catalog sales of cosmetics.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Tuition for her children

loans.name: Renovacion De Las Aguilas Group

texts.en:
Tania is the coordinator of her group Renovacion de Las Aguilas (Renewal of the Eagles), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the urban slums surrounding Santiago, an area known for tobacco production where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long-term partner and three children.

Tania is excited to be taking her third loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and expanded her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her ambulatory business selling clothing by purchasing men's, women's and children's clothing in the main markets in Santiago and then reselling them at a profit in her community . She will use the profits to save towards her goal of owning her own home. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: to purchase men's, women's and children's clothing to resell

loans.name: Saviour Group

texts.en:
Maron Z., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Saviour. She is 64 years old, married and has four children whose ages range from 18 to 38. She did not attend school due to poverty. She also cares for three siblings. 

For 15 years, she has been selling dried fish and meat at the ELWA Market on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia. She says customers are attracted to her business because she sells good dried fish and meat.

She plans to use her 8,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 40,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more dried fish and meat. She describes herself as a polite person. Her dream is to build a house and be able to assist other family members.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Anna is inset at the lower right because she was absent during the interview.

loans.use: To buy more dried fish and meat

loans.name: Irma Lucinda

texts.es:
Irma de 47 años, vive en una zona periurbana de Guayaquil, ella es costurera hace confecciones y cose ropa para su lista de clientes. Pero antes de que ella tuviera su negocio, Irma trabajo en una empresa  de confecciones pero la despidieron por reducción de personal, con sus ahorros compro una maquina de coser y empezó con su negocio.

En la actualidad ella tiene su negocio de costura y confección en su casa, trabaja desde las 08h00 hasta las 20h00pm todos los días. Pero para tener mas materiales de costura ella quiere comprar telas y hilos para su negocio. 

En el futuro quiere tener maquinas industriales para confeccionar al por mayor la ropa.
texts.en:
Irma is 47 years old. She lives in a periurban area of Guayaquil. She is a seamstress. She makes and sews clothes for her list of customers. Before she had a business, she worked for a company that makes clothes, but they let her go due to personnel reduction. She used her savings to buy a sewing machine, and she started her business. She currently has her business of sewing and making clothes in her house. She works from 8 a.m. until 8 p.m. everyday. In order to have more sewing materials she wants to buy fabric and thread for her business. In the future she wants to have industrial machines in order to make clothes to sell wholesale.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Fabric and thread

loans.name: Irene Janeth

texts.es: Irene Janeth tiene 31 años, su actividad es una pulpería. Hace más de 8 años que tiene esta actividad, pues siempre le ha gustado trabajar y sacrificarse para ganarse el pan de cada día. Sus inicios fueron muy duros ya que no tenía mucho apoyo de parte d su familia, pues no tenían el capital suficiente y es por medio de los financiamientos es que ha podido salir adelante, pues siempre se ha preocupado por mejorar su condición económica. El motivo del financiamiento es para la compra de golosinas, refrescos, pan, detergentes, jabón y sopas. Sueña con realizar mejoras en su vivienda.
texts.en:
Irene is 31 years old and has been running a general store for more than eight years and has always enjoyed working to earn her daily bread. It was difficult for her to get started, especially because she did not have her family’s support. They did not have the necessary capital, but she has used loans to help her get ahead. She has always concerned about getting ahead economically and will use the money from this loan to buy snacks, soft drinks, bread, detergents, soap, and soups. She would eventually like to make improvements to her home.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Mujeres Al Progreso Group

texts.en:
Yorkis is the coordinator of her group Mujeres Al Progreso (Women toward Progress), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in Puerto Plata, a port town located on the north coast of the DR, where the economy is based around tourism and where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure as a single mother with her three children.

Yorkis is excited to be taking her fifth loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and expanded her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business in which she acts as a sort of a gopher or intermediary, taking orders from clients and then arranging for them to be transported to the client. She will use the profits to invest in finishing the construction of her home and saving money to one day have a small location for her business. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: capital for her to purchase her clients' orders

loans.name: God Is Able Group

texts.en:
Vivian W., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called God Is Able. She is 31 years old, single and has three children whose ages range from 1 to 14. She is a college graduate. She also cares for two siblings. 

For 13 years, she has been selling slippers, underclothes and garments at the Fiamah Market in Sinkor, Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 17,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 84,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more slippers, underclothes and garments. She describes herself as a peaceful person. Her goal is to improve her business, make more profit and build a shop.

loans.use: To buy more slippers, underclothes and garments

loans.name: Nuevo Esfuerzo (G 4, 5) Group

texts.en:
Dilenia is the coordinator of her group Nuevo Esfuerzo (The New Effort), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in SemA., a lush rugged peninsula with a blossoming tourism industry, where, nevertheless, running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here as a single mother, in a simple structure with her three children.

Dilenia is excited to be taking her fifth loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loans and expanded her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her mobile variety sales business: to purchase clothes, sweets and other products for resale. She will use the profits to further expand and stabilize her business and to buy food, school supplies and medicine for her children. She hopes to better their future though her work. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy clothes, sweets and other products for resale

loans.name: Help Your Self Group

texts.en:
Jannet C., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Help Your Self. She is 44 years old, married and has five children whose ages range from 5 to 28. She could not continue her education in high school due to poverty. She also cares for two siblings. 

For 10 years, she has been selling frozen meat at the Fiamah Market in Sinkor, Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 8,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 36,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more cartons of frozen meat. She describes herself as easy-going and friendly. Her goal is to build a shop, travel and do international business.

loans.use: To buy more cartons of frozen meat

loans.name: Wanda De Los Angeles

texts.es: Wanda de los Ángeles tiene 24 años. Es una joven muy emprendedora, por lo que su actividad económica es la venta de mercadería en general, hace mas de 5 años que tiene esta actividad, pues no es el primer financiamiento que ella ha solicitado, ya que con ellos ha logrado mejorar su negocio.  Siempre está pensando en ampliar sus metas, pues es una mujer joven y que ha sabido mantener su negocio, con el paso del tiempo ha tenido la experiencia necesaria. El financiamiento es para la compra de perfumes, sabanas, toallas, cremas perfumes, tratamientos pues ya se acerca el día de la Madre pues ya tiene pedidos. Sueña con construir su propia casa.
texts.en:
Wanda de los Ángeles is 24 years old. She is an enterprising young woman who has been selling general merchandise for more than five years. This is not the first time she has requested a loan, so she has been able to utilize the financing in order to improve her business. Wanda is always thinking about expanding her goals. Even though she is a young woman, she has been able to maintain her business and gain necessary experience over time.

This loan will be used to buy perfumes, bed linens, towels, crèmes, perfumes, and treatments so that she can fulfill her orders for Mother’s Day. Wanda dreams of building her own home.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital to buy merchandise

loans.name: Maria Auxiliadora

texts.es: La señora Maria Auxiliadora es alguien responsable y disfruta de su trabajo, ella se dedica a la venta de comida, el negocio que está ubicado en su propia vivienda es visitado por muchos clientes que asisten a su local, en busca de los deliciosos platillos preparados por Maria, pues siempre está buscando nuevos platillos que ofrecer. Con el paso del tiempo Maria ha tenido experiencia y su negocio ha mejorado pero necesita más capital. Este el motivo del financiamiento para la compra de arroz, azúcar, aceite, frijoles, frutas verduras entre otras cosas.
texts.en:
Maria is a very responsible woman who enjoys her work; selling food. Her business, which is located within her own home, is visited by many customers who enjoy her many delicious dishes. She is always looking for new dishes to offer. Over time she has gained more experience and improved her business, but she needs more working capital. She will use the money from this loan to buy rice, sugar, cooking oil, beans, and fruits and vegetables, among other things.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Trusted Women Group

texts.en:
Annie D., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Trusted Women. She is 50 years old, married and has six children whose ages range from 7 to 30. All of her children attend school. She holds an associate degree and also cares for two siblings. 

For 4 years, she has been selling slippers and cream in Congo Town, Monrovia, Liberia. She says customers are attracted to her business because she sells quality products. She plans to use her 8,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 38,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more slippers and cream. Her goal is to improve her business and continue to support her children so that they can have a better future.

loans.use: To buy more slippers and cream

loans.name: Filadelfia Group

texts.es:
Una D. nuestras socias es la Sra. Norma, hace muchos años aperturo una imprenta la cual  dirige con mucho esmero y dedicación, allí elabora boletas, facturas y tarjetas para toda ocasión y todo los documentos que le solicitan.
Ella es casada y tiene 6 e hijos que la ayudan a seguir adelante, el objetivo D. Norma es que sus hijos sean profesionales y siente que lo está haciendo realidad, ya que una D. ellas estudia en la universidad, ella se siente contenta y con muchas ganas D. apoyar al grupo.

Gloria se dedica a comercializar condimentos y productos descartables como son vasos, platos y servilletas, en un mercado D. Chosica con la ayuda D. uno D. sus hijos y D. su esposo.  Comenzó este negocio hace 18 años juntamente con su esposo ahora con su esfuerzo día a día desea brindar lo mejor a sus 2 hijos. El grupo tiene alrededor D. 2 años trabajando con Edaprospo, en el cual demuestran responsabilidad en sus pagos.
texts.en:
Norma is one of our members. Many years ago she opened a printing business. She runs it very carefully with a great deal of dedication. She makes tickets, bills, and cards for all occasions. She makes all the documents that are requested. She is married and has six children, who help her get ahead. Norma’s goal is for her children to become professionals. She feels that she is making that a reality because one of her daughters is in the university. Norma is happy, and she has a great desire to support her group. Gloria sells condiments and disposable products like glasses, plates, and napkins. She sells, with help from one of her children and her husband, in the Chosica market. She and her husband started this business 18 years ago. Now, with her daily effort, she wishes to give her two children the best. The group has been working with Edaprospo for approximately two years. During that time they have been very responsible with their payments.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy products and supplies

loans.name: Fatima Del Rosario

texts.es: Fátima tiene 42 años. Su actividad es muy rentable y disfruta mucho de realizarla ya que tiene que dedicarles a sus hijos las oportunidades necesarias con sus estudios. Hace más de 8 años que se dedica al destace de cerdo pues gracias a su Madre que le enseño este rubro mejor notablemente así fue como ella logro independizarse y tener un medio de vida. El financiamiento es para la compra de  materia prima para la compra de cerdos. Sueña con seguir trabajando para mantener a su familia.
texts.en:
Fátima is 42. Her job is very profitable and she benefits greatly from it, since she has to offer her children educational opportunities. For more than 8 years she has been a pork butcher, thanks to her mother who taught her this work. Notably, this is how she achieved independence and a better livelihood. The loan is for the purchase of raw materials to buy pigs. She hopes to continue working to support her family.

Translated from Spanish by Christine Cooper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Emperatriz

texts.es:
Esperanza Martínez D. Z., resiD. en El Municipio D. Nueva Guadalupe del Departamento D. San Miguel, ella es casada vive con su esposo  y sus dos hijas D. 18 y 14 años respectivamente, el trabaja D. albañil y Esperanza tiene venta D. frutas, verduras y productos D. primera necesidad.
El negocio D.  venta D. frutas inicialmente era D. su madre quien se lo heredo, y actualmente ella  venD. sus productos en la casa D. evitación y regularmente para realizar más ventas D. lunes a viernes sale por las calles D. la zona D. nueva Guadalupe a ofrecer (tomates, repollo, manzanas, uvas, aguacate y otros), ella es una persona muy trabajadora, amable y responsable que gracias a su negocio, pueD. apoyar a sus hijas para que continúen con los estudios y solventar gastos del hogar.
Esperanza necesita el préstamo para comprar Frutas y verduras (zanahorias, cebollas, naranjas, manzanas, uvas, tomates) y ofrecer diferentes productos a sus cliente, sus aspiraciones son que con su esfuerzo y este dinero pueda mejorar la calidad D. vida D. su familia, que sus hijas terminen sus estudios, y algún día tener otro negocio D. venta D. frutas y verduras en El mercado.
texts.en:
Esperanza Martínez D. Z. lives in the municipality of Nueva Guadalupe in the Salvadoran "departamento" of San Miguel. She is married and lives with her husband and their two daughters, 18- and 14-years old, respectively. Esperanza's husband is a construction worker and Esperanza has a business selling fruits, vegetables and other everyday products. She learned the business from her mother and now sells her products at the "casa D. evitacion y regularmente" where her sales are higher. From Mondays to Fridays she works as a street vendor, selling her products (tomatoes, cabbage, apples, grapes, avocados, etc.) around Nueva Guadalupe. Esperanza is a hard-working woman, friendly and responsible, who--thanks to the business--can pay household bills and support her daughters so that they can continue with their schooling. Esperanza needs the loan to buy fruits and vegetables (carrots, onions, oranges, apples, grapes, tomatoes) so that she can offer a range of products to her customers. Her greatest hopes are that her efforts and this money can help improve her family's quality of life; that her daughters finish their studies; and that she can one day have a fruit and vegetable business in the market.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy products for resale.

loans.name: Maria Catalina

texts.es:
María Catalina Gómez Z., resiD. en ciudad D. San Miguel, ella tiene 55 años D. edad, vive con su esposo, su madre y un hijo, ella se dedica a la venta D. ropa,
Hace 20 años se dedica a la venta D. ropa para dama, caballeros y niños, con mucho esfuerzo  comercializa  la ropa D.  8:00 am - 4: 00 pm, en las calles del mercado municipal D. San Miguel, ya que considera que D. esta forma venD. más, D. Lunes a Sábado, los domingos descansa y va a la iglesia  con su familia, es una persona muy amable, responsable y dedicada con su trabajo ya que con mucho sacrificios a logrado construir su casa.
María hoy se ha visto en la necesidad D. adquirir el préstamo para comprar dos puertas prefabricadas y láminas para mejorar el techo D. su cocina, ya que por las noches no posee seguridad, con la instalación D. las puertas ya no correría el peligro que le roben sus cosas, sus aspiraciones son seguir trabajando y está segura que con el crédito va a  mejorar la calidad D. vida D. sus familia, ya que este tipo D. apoyo es el que permite a mucha personas solventar las necesidades.
texts.en:
María Catalina Gómez Z., 55, lives in the city of San Miguel. She lives with her husband, her mother and a son. She makes a living selling clothes. For 20 years, she has worked selling clothes for women, men and children, working hard every day, from 8:00am to 4:00pm, as a street vendor in the area around the municipal market of San Miguel. She works from Monday to Saturday. On Sunday, she rests and goes to church with her family. Maria is a friendly person, responsible and hard-working. With much sacrifice, she has managed to build her own house, but she now needs a loan to buy two prefabricated doors and material for improving the roof over her kitchen. Someone could easily break into the house and rob it now, so the doors will reduce the risk of being robbed. Maria wants to continue working. She is sure that this loan will help her to improve her family's quality of life because this kind of support has improved the lives of others.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy construction materials.

loans.name: Ginia Areli

texts.es: Ginia Areli tiene 30 años, su actividad es brindar el servicio de videos juegos, además de esto realiza la venta de comida y refrescos los días de semana. Hace más de 2 años que tiene esta actividad pues siempre busca la forma de diversificar su actividad ella tiene 2 hijos y quiere proporcionarles los estudios correspondientes a sus hijos, ya siempre lucha y se esfuerza por ellos. Es por eso que solicita este financiamiento como una oportunidad para salir adelante con su actividad. Desea ampliar su negocio lo suficiente para que pueda ser rentable.
texts.en:
Ginia Areli is 30. She rents video game services, and also sells food and refreshments on weekdays. She has been doing this for over 2 years, and she is always looking to diversify her business. Gina Areli has 2 children and wants to provide them with education; she is always fighting and struggling for them. For this reason she is requesting this loan as an opportunity to get ahead with her business. She wants to expand her business enough to make it profitable.

Translated from Spanish by Christine Cooper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Librado

texts.es:
El señor Librado H. esta muy agradecido por su cooperación en el crédito anterior el cual pudo empezar L. construcción D. una cuarto. 
Esta nuevamente solicitando un préstamo para terminar L. recamara que será para sus hijos.
Planea pagar el crédito con una parte del sueldo que recibe como guardia D. un compañía bancaria D. L. ciudad.
texts.en:
Librado H. is very grateful for his previous loan which allowed him to begin to build a room. He is requesting a new loan to finish the bedroom that will be his children's. He plans to repay the loan with part of the salary he earns as a guard for a banking company in the city.

Translated from Spanish by Christine Cooper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To build a room

loans.name: Lidia Del Transito

texts.es: Lidia del Transito tiene la edad de 55 años. Su actividad es la venta de refrescos, además tiene otra actividad que es venta de lácteos y ropa interior. Su actividad consiste en vender estos productos que son muy importantes para ella, siempre busca la manera de mejorar y ampliar cada día su actividad. Su mayor sueño es establecer una pulpería muy grande. Por lo que el financiamiento que solicita es para la compra de materia prima que será destinado para la inversión de su negocio.
texts.en:
Lidia Del Transito is 55 years old. Her main activity is selling sodas, milk, and undergarments; products that are very important to her. She is always looking for a way to improve and expand her daily business. Her biggest dream is to establish a very large grocery store. The loan requested is to purchase raw material which will be used to invest back in her business.

Translated from Spanish by Gustavo Gutierrez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Luchando Con Esperanza  1,2 Group

texts.en:
Yesenia is the coordinator of her group Luchando Con Esperanza (Fighting with Hope), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in Puerto Plata, a port town on the north coast, where the economy is based around tourism and where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her husband and three children.

Yesenia is excited to be taking her first loan with Esperanza and she is excited to invest in her business which, in true entrepreneurial spirit, is a combination cafeteria and boutique. She plans to buy rice for the cafeteria and pants, blouses and shirts to sell in the boutique. She will use the profits to invest in her children by purchasing school supplies and uniforms and she will also save towards expanding her business. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: to buy rice, pants, blouses and shirts

loans.name: Amarilis Del Establo Group

texts.es:
LA SRA J., TIENE 24 AÑOS DE EDAD, TIENE DOS PEQUEÑOS HIJOS. ELLA FORMA PARTE DEL GRUPO "AMARILIS DEL ESTABLO" CUYOS 8 SOCIOS VIVEN EN LA ZONA DE RAMIRO PRIALE EN EL DISTRITO DE CARABAYLLO.

LA SRA. J., SE DEDICA A LA ADMINISTRACIÓN Y ATENCIÓN DE SU BODEGA, TRABAJO QUE LE DEMANDA TODO EL DÍA, INIÓ ÉSTE NEGOCIO CON EL INCENTIVO DE SU HERMANO, QUIEN LA ANIMÓ Y LE ASEGURÓ QUE TENDRÍA ÉXITO, NO LE HA IDO MAL, PERO ELLA SIGUE TRABAJANDO CON MUCHO ENTUSIASMO PARA HACER CRECER EL NEGOCIO, ADEMÁS ESÉSTE SU FUENTE DE INGRESO, GRACIAS A ELLO PUEDE ASUMIR LOS GASTOS FAMILIARES, ARREGLAR DE A POCOS SU CASITA Y PAGAR EL COLEGIO DE SUS HIJOS.
SU PROXIMA META ES COMPRAR SU CASA.
EL PRESTAMO SOLICITADO LO INVERTIRÁ EN LA COMPRA DE BEBIDAS PARA SURTIR SU BODEGA.
texts.en:
Mrs. Davalos Fuertes is 24 years old, she has two small children. She is part of the group " Amarilis Del Establo" whose 8 other associates live in the Ramiro Priale area, a district of Carabayllo. Mrs. Davalos Fuertes is in charge of running her grocery store, a job demanding her entire day. She began the business with the encouragement of her brother who encouraged her and assured her success. Business hasn't been bad but she continues working with enthusiasm to grow the business since this is her main source of income. Thanks to the business she can cover her familie's expenses, slowly fix up her home, and pay for her children's schooling. Her next goal is to pay off her home. The loan requested would be vested towards the purchase of beverages to stock the grocery store.

Translated from Spanish by Gustavo Gutierrez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in puchase of beverages to stock the grocery store

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy food supplies

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase clothing to resell

loans.name: Ebenezer 3 Group

texts.en:
Linda is the coordinator of her group Ebenezer, and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the urban slums surrounding Santiago, an area known for its tobacco production, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure.

Linda is excited to be taking her second loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and expanded her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her mobile business selling clothing by purchasing pants, t-shirts and dress shirts to sell. She will use the profits to save towards her goal of purchasing a motorcycle to help her transport and sell her goods. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: to buy pants, dress shirts and t-shirts to resell

loans.name: Cristo Viene (Grupo 5) Group

texts.en:
Sara is the coordinator of her group Cristo Viene (Christ is Coming), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in Samana, a lush rugged peninsula with a blossoming tourism industry, where, nevertheless, running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple house, as a single mother with two children.

Sara is excited to be taking her second loan with Esperanza, after having successfully repaid her previous loan and expanded her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her small sewing/clothing sales business she runs out of her home. She would like to buy a sewing machine and some supplies: bedsheets, curtains, pillows, fabric, etc. She will use the profits to make improvements to the structure which houses her home/business and towards her children's well-being, by purchasing school supplies and other essentials. She hopes to be able to keep her business stable to ensure a good future for her family. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: to buy supplies and a sewing machine

loans.name: Hilda Eliethe

texts.es: Hilda Eliethe tiene 33 años, su actividad es la venta de comida y refresco. Hace más  de 3 años que tiene este negocio por lo que siempre ha sido una persona responsable que paga sus cuotas en tiempo y forma. Además todos los días se alista temprano para  buscar el pan de cada día, algunas veces llueve y ella tiene que buscar el medio para la trasladarse a su negocio, pues tiene que llevar ciertas cosas de su vivienda. El financiamiento que solicita es para la compra de materia prima necesaria. Sueña con seguir trabajando y obtener más clientes.
texts.en:
Hilda Eliethe is 33-years-old. She sells food and soft drinks. She's had this business for more than 3 years because she's a responsible person who always makes her payments in due time and proper form. Everyday she wakes up early for work and sometimes it rains and she has to look for transportation to her business while carrying things from home. She is asking for a loan to buy necessary merchandise. Her dream is to continue working and gain more customers.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Richardson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Santa Colastica

texts.es:
Santa de 63 años, V. en una zona periurbana en el Fortín de Guayaquil. Ella tiene una tienda de víveres, por la falta de oportunidades y los pocos ingresos de su esposo ella decidió readecuar la sala de su casa y convertirla en una pequeña tienda. Empezó vendiendo bebidas y bolos( es una funda llena de jugo congelado). 

Poco a poco fue incrementando los productos que vendía, así continuo hasta ahora que tiene una tienda surtida y trabaja desde las 08h00am hasta las 19h00pm todos los días. Para tener aun mas surtido su negocio quiere comprar víveres, bebidas, enlatados etc. 

En el futuro quiere tener mas grande su tienda para tener asegurada la vejez.
texts.en:
Santa, 63, lives on the outskirts of Guayaquil. She operates a small grocery because there are few opportunities to do anything else and because her husband's meager income isn't enough to pay their bills. She decided to convert the living room of her house to a small shop and began selling drinks and "bolos" (a shell filled with frozen juice). Little by little, she's added to the products that she sells so that she now has a well-stocked store. She works every day from 8:00am to 7:00pm. To better stock her store, she wants to buy everyday products, drinks, canned goods, etc. In the future, she wants to expand her store so that she will have some security as she grows older.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy products to resell

loans.name: La Buena Fe 5 Group

texts.en:
Marta is the coordinator of her group L. Buena Fe (The Good Faith). Her story is representative of her group and generally of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients, many of whom recently emigrated to the Dominican Republic from Haiti. Her group is located in the rural areas surrounding Hato Mayor, a sleepy agricultural town where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long-term partner.

Marta is excited to be taking her third loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling jewelry. She intends to use the loan capital to purchase underwear in order to expand her offerings. She will use the profits to complete construction on her home and to invest in her children's education. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To purchase underwear to sell

loans.name: Reyna Elizabeth

texts.es: Reyna Elizabeth tiene 24 años, su actividad es la venta de cosméticos. Hace más de 3 años que tiene esta actividad, Pero antes de que ella tuviera su negocio, no tenía trabajo pero con ciertos ahorros decide quedarse en una casa comercial, en donde ella ofrece los diferentes productos por catálogos, así es como ella empieza a ganarse la vida y realzar un sin número de visitas a todas las personas que conoce a pesar que los recorridos son largo mantiene la esperanza de que mejorar sus situación. El crédito será para la compra de cremas, colonias, tratamientos, ropa interior y otras cosas. su deseo es seguir con este negocio.
texts.en:
Reyna Elizabeth is 24-years-old. She sells cosmetics. She's done this for more than 3 years. Before starting her business she didn't have work, but with some savings she decided to set up in a commercial center, where she offers various products from catalogs. That's how she started making a living. She's been making countless sales visits to everyone she knows, and even though the trips are long she maintains hope that this work will improve her situation. The loan will be for the purchase of creams, colognes, beauty treatments, underwear, and other things. She hopes to maintain this business.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Richardson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cosmetics

loans.name: Esmirna (G1,3) Group

texts.en:
Olga is the coordinator of her group Esmirna. Her story is representative of her group and generally of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients, many of whom recently emigrated to the Dominican Republic from Haiti. Her group is located in La Romana, a rural area of the country dedicated to the sugar cane harvest, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She and her husband make their home here in a simple structure.

Olga is excited to be taking her fifth loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loans and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling clothes and various other items. She intends to buy shoes, perfumes, and other products to sell. She will use the profits to make improvements to her house and will invest in the well-being of her family. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy clothes, shoes, and perfumes for a small store.

loans.name: Maria Isabel

texts.es: Maria tiene 45 años y 1 hijo que está estudiando, Maria se dedica a la venta de cosméticos por catálogos, que ofrece a amigos y familiares, con lo cual obtiene un ingreso para su familia. Los sueños de Maria es que su hijo pueda asistir a una universidad y logre ser un buen profesional. Maria necesita un préstamo  dinero que será invertido en la compra de perfumes, cremas por lo que se preocupa de generar ingresos para el alimento diario. Sueña con tener su propio medio de transporte que le facilite la entrega de sus productos.
texts.en:
Maria is 45-years-old and she has 1 child in school. Maria sells cosmetics from catalogs that she offers to her friends and relatives in order to make an income for her family. Maria's dream is that her son will be able to attend a university and become a professional. She needs a loan that she will invest in the purchase of perfumes, creams, and whatever else is necessary to generate enough income to put food on the table. She hopes one day to have her own mode of transportation that will facilitate the delivery of her products.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Richardson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of perfumes, creams, and other cosmetics

loans.name: Mujeres Del Nuevo Renacer 3,4 Group

texts.en:
Balbina is the coordinator of her group Mujeres del Nuevo Renacer (Women of Rebirth). Her story is representative of her group and generally of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients, many of whom recently emigrated to the Dominican Republic from Haiti. Her group is located in Puerto Plata, a northern port town where the economy is based on tourism and where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her husband and two children.

Balbina is excited to be taking her fifth loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business running a beauty salon, which also happens to be a sandwich shop. She will use the capital to purchase two different lines of hair products, as well as salami, ham, and cheese. She will use the profits to invest in a space to rent for her salon, as well as to construct a second floor to her home to rent out for extra money. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To purchase hair products and sandwich ingredients

loans.name: Oscar Enrique

texts.es:
El Señor Oscar está casado tiene 3 hijos que están a su cargo.
Desde hace 6  años se dedica a la venta de artículos de primera necesidad en su propio local. Por lo que no es la primera vez que realiza créditos, pues son muy importantes para el desarrollo de su local. Oscar acudió a la Fundación para que atreves de un crédito pudiera invertir en la compra de mercadería azúcar, detergente, arroz, jugos y pan para surtir más su negocio.
Con esta actividad el consigue ayudar a su esposa quien no posee un ingreso fijo. En un futuro el  señor quiere seguir ampliando su clientela y así obtener una mayor ganancia de su negocio.
texts.en:
Oscar is married and has 3 children whom he cares for. For 6 years he has sold basic items in his own store. This is not his first loan; loans are very important for the development of his business. Oscar turned to the Fundacion so that, through a loan, he could invest in the purchase of merchandise: sugar, detergent, rice, juices and bread to increase his stock. With this job he is able to help his wife who has no fixed income. In the future he wants to expand his customer base and thus increase his earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Christine Cooper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital-general store

loans.name: Con Cristo Y Nuestro Esfuerzo Group

texts.en:
Maria is the coordinator of her group Con Cristo y Nuestro Esfuerzo (With Christ and our Effort), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients generally — many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti. Her group is located in L. Romana, a rural area of the country dedicated to the sugar cane harvest, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure, alone with her three children.

Maria is excited to be taking her second loan with Esperanza, after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her small cafeteria by buying essential supplies: big bottles of water (which she also sells), meat, soft drinks, bread, fruit, etc. She will use the profits to develop her business further and to better the living conditions of her family. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy food supplies for a small cafeteria: water, meat, soft drinks, bread, fruit etc.

loans.name: Aura Sofia

texts.es:
Si usted conoce a la señora Aura O., identifica la naturaleza de negociante que la caracteriza, pues aunque no tiene maquinaria, ofrece vestidos para niñas y accesorios a la medida y al gusto de sus clientes; su negocio consiste en comprar telas  e insumos de modistería para mandarle a fabricar a 3 confeccionistas, los mas fantásticos vestidos, combinados con accesorios armónicos y adornos como sombreros cintillos, binchas adornadas, para niñas que participan como ninfas, damas de honor en matrimonios, o en cumpleaños, bautizos y ocasiones elegantes y especiales de las familias. Mediante este sistema Aura  suministra a crédito y a muy buen precio sus productos, porque para ella es  muy  claro que con su calidad en los precios ella compite. Sus clientes   son  almacenes en los centro de Barranquilla y en muchas ciudades y municipios de la costa caribe como Bosconia, en el Departamento del Cesar,  Cienaga en el Departamento del Magdalena y Montería en el Departamento de Córdoba,  donde viaja semanalmente llevando sus productos  junto a su libreta de cuentas por cobrar para recuperar su dinero.

Ella trabaja en horario extendido y ha progresado mucho desde su primer crédito con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo hasta la presente, sus ventas se han incrementado en un 50% y así mismo sus ingresos y utilidades. Hoy está solicitando su tercer financiamiento y desea prepararse para la temporada alta del segundo semestre del año, comprando materias primas al  por mayor y de contado e insumos como telas y adornos para poder mandar a elaborar los diseños mas apetecidos.
Su meta y gran desafío es hacer de sus hijos unos profesionales, ya que la mayor se gradúa este año como bachiller y el menor terminará su nivel de primaria, por lo que tiene que  seguir realizando muchos esfuerzos  desde su populoso barrio ubicado en el sur de Barranquilla muy cerca de centros comerciales y del famoso estadio donde juega el equipo de futbol que mas quiere la ciudad: “El Junior de Barranquilla”
texts.en:
If you knew Señora Aura O., you’d know that she personifies “saleswoman.” Even though she doesn’t have machines, she sells little girls’ dresses and accessories to the size and preference of her customers. Her business is buying material and dressmaking supplies to send out to three seamstresses. The most fantastic dresses combined with the right accessories and adornments like headbands for hats and decorated binchas for girls who participate as nymphs, bridesmaids, or in birthdays, baptisms, elegant occasions, and special family events. Through this system Aura sells her products on credit, and at a good price, because it is very clear to her that quality and price compete. Her customers are stores in Barranquilla and in many cities and municipalities of the Caribbean coast like Bosconia in the Department of Cesar, Cienaga in the Department of Magdalena, and Montería in the Department of Córdoba where she travels weekly bringing her products alongside her accounting book to collect her money. She works extended hours and has progressed a lot since her first loan with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo to the present. Her sales have increased by 50% as well as her earnings and profits. Today she is taking out her third loan and wants to get ready for the high season (the second semester of the year) by buying wholesale raw materials and supplies like fabrics and decorations, paying in full, to be able to send out to have the best designs made. Her goal, and great challenge, is to make her children professionals since the oldest graduates from high school this year and the youngest finishes grade school. She has to keep going as much as possible from her populous neighborhood, south of Barranquilla, very close to malls and the famous stadium where the city’s most beloved team “El Junior de Barranquilla” plays.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Wholesale raw materials and supplies -- paid in full (fabrics, accessories, decorations)

loans.name: Oscar Antonio

texts.es: El señor Oscar Antonio tiene el negocio que es una pulpería ubicada en su casa de habitación,  realiza sus compras de contado a camiones repartidores, sus ventas las efectúa de contado y al crédito.  Sus padres fueron los que desde chico le inculcaron y le enseñaron todo lo relacionado al comercio, pues siempre tuvieron negocio. Cuando empezó a ser independiente, busca la forma de cómo generar ingresos a su familia. Esta solicitando un nuevo financiamiento para invertirlo en su negocio y hacerlo más productivo.
texts.en:
Oscar Antonio has a business, which is a minimarket in his house. He buys his supplies for cash from delivery trucks. His sales are for cash or credit. His parents were the ones that influenced him and taught him everything about business. They always had a business. When he started to become independent, he looked for the way to generate income for his family. He is requesting a new loan to invest in his business to make it more productive.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Violeta 2 Group

texts.en:
Tomasas is the coordinator of her group Violeta (Violet), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients generally — many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti. Her group is located in Los Alcarrizos, a dusty urban area where there are many free trade zones and where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple, rented structure with her long-term partner and their child.

Tomasa is excited to be taking out her fifth loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loans and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling clothing and cosmetics by purchasing more merchandise. She will use the profits to finish construction of her home so that she can move from her current rented space. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics and clothes to sell

loans.name: Milagro De Cumayasa Group

texts.en:
Alma is the coordinator of her group Milagro D. Cumayasa (The Miracle of Cumayasa), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients generally — many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti. Her group is located in L. Romana, a rural area of the country dedicated to the sugar cane harvest, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her life-long partner and two children.

Alma is excited to be taking out her second loan with Esperanza, after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her small clothing sales business by purchasing necessary supplies: undergarments and other clothes. She will use the profits to continue her university studies and improve the quality of life for her family. She also hopes to be able to buy a house sometime in the future. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy undergarments and other clothes for sale.

loans.name: Fernando Ernesto

texts.es: El señor Fernando Ernesto tiene su negocio que es el  destace de res o ganado vacuno, el realiza la compra de el ganado de contado a diferentes campesinos y sus comarcas, las ventas las realiza de contado y al crédito a diferentes pulperías. El se levanta muy temprano pues tiene que realizar la entrega de estos productos, en algunas circunstancias tiene que mojarse pues el clima no lo detiene a seguir con trabajo.   Además cuenta con la ayuda de su esposa la cual posee una pulpería y a si con ello aumentan los ingresos del hogar. El financiamiento es para la compra de materia prima para la compra de materia prima necesaria en su negocio y satisfacer la demanda de sus clientes.
texts.en:
Fernando Ernesto’s business is butchering cattle. He buys the cattle for cash from people in different regions. He sells for cash or credit to different grocery stores. He gets up very early because he has to deliver these products. Sometimes he gets wet because the weather does not keep him from getting on with his work. His wife, who has a grocery store, helps him. This helps increase the household income. The loan is to buy the raw material he needs for his business in order to satisfy customer demand.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Blanca Nacisa

texts.es:
Blanca de 26 años, vive en una zona periurbana en Guayaquil, su casa es de caña y solo cuenta con luz como servicio básico, ella tiene una tienda de especies de ( acelga, albahaca, achiote, alcaparra, alfalfa etc.). Antes de tener su tienda de especies ella trabajaba en un almacén pero por la reducción del personal la despidieron y se quedo sin trabajo. 

Pero por su esfuerzo y el dinero ahorrado que tenia compro especies alimenticias(las que aparecen en la foto) y empezó a vender en su casa a todas las personas que la conocían. En la actualidad ella trabaja todos los días vendiendo especies alimenticias. Quiere con el préstamo comprar especies y readecuar mas su negocio con vitrinas.  

En el futuro quiere expandir su negocio con mas tienda de especies.
texts.en:
Blanca, age 26, lives in the periurban area of Guayaquil. Her house is made of wood, and the only basic service she has is electricity. She has a spice store (chard, basil, annatto, capers, and alfalfa). Before she had her spice store she worked in a store. Due to a reduction in personnel, they let her go. She was left without work. Through her effort and the money she had saved she bought spices (they appear in the photo). She started to sell in her house to everyone she knew. She currently works everyday selling spices. She wants the loan to buy spices and to recondition her store with display cases. In the future she wants to expand her business with more spice stores.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Display case and spices

loans.name: Alma Nubia

texts.es: Alma Nubia tiene 50 años de edad, tiene 2 hijos que trabajan por cuenta propia. Ella se dedica al servicio taxi urbano. Por lo que ella lo alquila para que puedan trabajarlo de esta manera ella brinda trabajo a la persona que lo solicite, siendo este el único medio ingreso que tiene para sobrevivir, hace más de 13 años que tiene este negocio. El crédito será destinado para compra de repuestos para el automóvil, llantas, frenos entre otras cosas. ella desea tener un nuevo vehículo para darlo a trabajar.
texts.en:
Alma Nubia is 50 years old. She has two children who work independently. She devotes herself to urban taxi service. She rents the taxi in order to be able to have it working. This way she provides work for the person who asks for it. This is the only income she has to survive on. She has had this business for over 13 years. The loan will be to buy replacement parts for the automobile. She will buy tires and brakes, among other things. She wishes to have a new vehicle in order to put it to work.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Luchando Para Vivir 1, 2 Group

texts.en:
Lidia is the coordinator of her group Luchando Para Vivir (Fighting to Live), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients generally — many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti. Her group is located in the urban slums surrounding Santiago an area known for its tobacco production where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure as a widow with her three children.

Lidia is excited to be taking out her first loan with Esperanza and is excited to increase her income. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling natural medicines by buying more of the necessary ingredients. She will use the profits to improve her home. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: Natural medicines to sell

loans.name: Luis Antonio

texts.es: Luis Antonio tiene 24 años  este joven emprendedor ha dado de todo con su negocio que es brindar el servicio de enderezado de pinturas. Hace más de 6 años que tiene este negocio, inicio por su Padre que desde muy pequeño le enseño este negocio para que sobreviviera, actualmente tiene ciertas dificultades como lo es el tiempo pues tiene que realizar los pedidos en tiempo y forma es por eso que cada día se empeña y esfuerza para complacer a sus clientes. Este crédito lo solicita para la compra de herramientas, pinturas, aerosoles, cintas entre otras cosas. Sueña con ampliar su negocio y algún día tener la fama de su Papa.
texts.en:
Luis Antonio, 24, is a young entrepreneur who has given everything to his business, which is an auto body shop. He has had this business for more than 6 years. It was started by his father, who taught him the business from the time that he was very young so that the business would survive. Currently he has certain problems, for example with time, as he must carry out his orders on time and as directed. For this reason, each day he works and strives to please his customers. The loan he requests is to buy tools, paints, aerosols, and belts, among other items. He dreams of expanding his business and one day of having a reputation as good as his father's.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital to buy tools and supplies

loans.name: Carlos Alberto

texts.es: Carlos Alberto tiene la actividad de venta de mercadería en general. Hace más de 5 años que tiene este negocio por lo que le ha gustado conversar con sus clientes, pues el siempre se esfuerza por proporcionar un buen servicio para no perder la clientela. El visita a muchas personas pues tiene que salir a ofrecer sus diferentes productos. El financiamiento que solicita es para la compra de materia prima como cosméticos, perfumes, bolsos, sabanas, colonias entre otras cosas. Su deseo es obtener nuevos clientes y ampliar su negocio.
texts.en:
Carlos Alberto sells general merchandise, and he has had this business for more than 5 years. He enjoys conversing with his customers, and he is always striving to provide the best service so as to avoid losing customers. He visits many people because he has to go out to offer his different products. The loan he requests is to buy merchandise such as cosmetics, perfumes, handbags, bed sheets, colognes, and other things. He hopes to get new customers and expand his business.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital to buy merchandise such as cosmetics, bags and perfumes

loans.name: Juana Antonia

texts.es: Juana Antonia de 38 años, vive en una zona bastante lejana. Hace 12 años que se dedica a la venta de mercadería en general, productos como cucharas, tenedores, tasas, electrodomésticos entre otras cosas. Ella siempre se ha esforzado por tener un tramo en donde puede ofrecer diferentes productos y que sus clientes observen con mejor comodidad. Poco a poco fue incrementando su tienda, aunque no cuenta con muchos productos ella sigue trabajando para incrementarlos. El sueño de ella es mejorar su vivienda. El financiamiento es para la compra de materia prima.
texts.en:
Juana Antonia is 38 years old and lives in a remote area. For twelve years she has been selling general merchandise such as spoons, forks, cups, household appliances, and other products. She always strives to keep her vending station stocked with a variety of different products so that her customers will find it more convenient to shop there. Gradually over time she has expanded her store. Although she does not have many products, she continually works toward increasing her inventory. Her dream is to make improvements to her home.

This loan will be used to buy more materials.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital

loans.name: María Mercedes

texts.es: María Mercedes tiene mucho tiempo de trabajar con Fundación. Tiene 3 hijos a cargo. Su actividad económica es la venta de mercadería en general.  Pues Hace más de 6 años que se dedica a esta actividad, su esposo le ayuda a sufragar los gastos del hogar. Maria ha trabajado con esfuerzo y dedicación durante los años. Sus resultados han sido favorables para que siga con su negocio. El dinero que solicita es para capital de trabajo para la compra de productos como pantalones, camisas, shorts, faldas y camisetas. Sueña con ampliar más su actividad y mantenerla activa.
texts.en:
María Mercedes has been working with Fundación for a long time. She has 3 children to care for. Her business activity is the sale of general merchandise. She has been in this line of business for over 6 years, and her husband helps her with household expenses. María's hard work and dedication over the years have given good results and have enabled her to continue with her business. The money she is requesting is for work capital and will go towards the purchase of products such as trousers, shirts, shorts, skirts and t-shirts. Her dream is to expand her business and keep it active.

Translated from Spanish by Alba Sort , Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Work capital

loans.name: Sara

texts.es:
Sara tiene 33 años D. edad, es casada y tiene un pequeño hijo, vive junto a su familia en el distrito D. Mórrope, un distrito caracterizado por tener a la mayoría D. su población concentrada en un pueblo central y en varios caseríos que distan mucho uno del otro, pertenece a la provincia D. Lambayeque y se encuentra ubicado a 45 minutos D. la ciudad D. Chiclayo.

Sara ha estudiado la carrera técnica D. enfermería y actualmente se vale D. sus estudios para percibir ingresos, lleva diez años trabajando en centros D. salud D. la zona rural D. su distrito. Esta labor le provee D. ingresos estables con los cuales ayuda a su esposo en el sostenimiento D. su hogar. 

Adicionalmente se dedica desD. hace seis años a la comercialización D. aves D. corral, compra aves a los pobladores D. los caseríos D. Mórrope, las engorda y las ofrece en venta en la ciudad D. Chiclayo. Eventualmente también compra pescado y lo venD. en su vivienda a sus vecinos.

Sara nos comenta que estas actividades le han servido para salir adelante y ahora su familia ya cuenta con una vivienda propia, además siente que con el trabajo que realiza en los caseríos D. la zona ayuda a los lugareños a tener una mejor calidad D. vida. Ella desea trabajar un poco mas para poder percibir una mayor cantidad D.  ingresos ya que su menor hijo ingresará muy pronto a estudiar, por ello ha solicitado por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crrédito D. 800 nuevos soles que piensa invertir en la compra D. aves D. corral para ampliar su negocio D. comercialización.

Sara es una mujer alegre y que trabaja siempre pensando en el bienestar D. su familia. Su mayor anhelo es mejorar la infraestructura D. su vivienda que aun esta construida D. material rustico. En la zona donD. vive ella es muy querida y estimada por sus vecinos.
texts.en:
Sara, age 33, is married and has a young son. She lives with her family in the Mórrope district. This district is noted for having the majority of its population concentrated in a central town and in various rural communities that are very far from each other. The district belongs to the Lambayeque province. It is 45 minutes from the city of Chiclayo. Sara has studied for a career as a technical nurse. She currently relies on her studies to get income. She has been working in health centers in rural areas of her district for ten years. This work provides a stable income, which helps her husband support the household. Also, she has been selling poultry for six years. She buys birds from the people who live in the rural area of Mórrope. She fattens them and sells them in the city of Chiclayo. Occasionally she also buys fish and sells it in her house to her neighbors. Sara tells us that these activities have been useful to her in order to get ahead. Now her family has their own home. Also, she feels that the work she does in the rural areas helps the villagers to have a better quality of life. She wants to work a little more to be able to get a greater income because her youngest child will be registering for school very soon. That is why she has asked, for the first time, Edpyme Alternative for a loan of 800 PEN. She will use it to buy poultry to expand her business of selling poultry. Sara is a happy woman, and she always works thinking of her family’s well-being. Her greatest desire is to improve the infrastructure of her house because it is still maD. of adobe. In the area where she lives she is loved and respected by her neighbors.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy poultry to expand her business of raising them and selling them

loans.name: Emprendiendo Sin Fronteras Group

texts.es:
LA SRA. ANTONIA TIENE 45 AÑOS, ES CASADA Y TIENE 3 HIJOS. ELLA INTEGRA EL GRUPO "EMPRENDIENDO SIN FRONTERAS", JUNTO CON 7 PERSONAS MÁS, RESIDENTES DEL DISTRITO D. COMAS, QUIENES LA ELIGIERON COMO TESORERA D. LA JUNTA DIRECTIVA DEL GRUPO.
ELLA SE DEDICA HACE DOS AÑOS A ATENDER SU TIENDA D. ABARROTES D. NOMBRE "BODEGUITA TRINIDAD", INICIÓ EN UN LOCAL ALQUILADO UBICADO FRENTE A UN MERCADO, LUEGO D. SUFRIR UN ROBO SE MUDO A SU CASA DOND. LE VA MUY BIEN.
CON SU TRABAJO PUED. APOYAR A SU HIJA EN LOS GASTOS D. LA UNIVERSIDAD E IN CONSTRUYENDO D. A POQUITOS SU CASITA.
EL PRÉSTAMO SOLICITADO LO INVERTIRÁ PARA COMPRAR INSUMOS PARA INSTALAR UN NEGOCIO D. COMIDA.
texts.en:
Mrs. Antonia is 45 years old, married with 3 children. She is part of the "Emprendiendo Sin Fronteras" group alongsiD. 7 more people living in the Comas district, who elected her as treasurer of the group's managing board. She has been managing her grocery store, called "Bodeguita Trinidad", for two years. She started off in rented premises opposite a market. After having been robbed she moved the business to her own home, where things are going well. With her work she supports her daughter's university expenses and slowly builds her own home. She will invest the requested loan in the purchase of food supplies to start a food business.

Translated from Spanish by Alba Sort , Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in a food business

loans.name: Yinaira Paola

texts.es:
Yinaira Paola Gutiérrez Quiroz es una joven que vive con su cónyuge e hijo de un año en el barrio de Bellavista de la municipalidad de Malambo, cerca de Barranquilla.  Yinaira es una vendedora de víveres, artesianas, y almuerzos. Es tradicional en este sector que las personas consuman sopa a la hora del almuerzo, por lo que es común ver varios negocios similares, pero a su microempresa la prefieren. Su negocio fue iniciado por su madre hace 20 años después de haber tenido en el mercado de Barraquilla un puesto de mayorista de verduras. Se inicio con una tienda, que ahora tiene arrendada y después montó una miscelánea, pero esta última no tuvo mucho éxito por la competencia y debió cerrarla, lo cual fué uno de sus desafíos mas difíciles. En el ano 2005 en vista de la demanda de almuerzos y sopas en el sector decidió iniciar  este negocio para vender a sus vecinos y a varios establecimientos comerciales cercanos a su vivienda. Es precisamente para fortalecer este negocio que requiere el crédito, ya que debe ampliar el local y adquirir nuevos sillas e implementos para cocina como ollas, platos y cubiertos. Además obtiene otros ingresos por tejidos que elabora de prendas de resistir y bolsos los cuales envía a Medellín, una ciudad importante de Colombia, para su comercialización. Necesita adecuar el sitio y para ello requiere un techo a la entrada a fin de hacer el negocio da almuerzos mas visible y fresco

Será el segundo crédito que Yinaira ha recibido de la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo. Desde que comenzó con FMSD, logró incrementar su nivel de ventas y mejorar sus ingresos y esto es mejorar su nivel de vida e irse haciendo a electrodomésticos para su uso.. Siguiendo hacia delante, ella espera organizar el punto de venta de almuerzos con el fin de incrementar sus ingresos.
texts.en:
Yinaira Paola Gutiérrez Quiroz is a young woman who lives with her spouse and one-year-old son in Malambo’s Bellavista neighborhood near Barranquilla. She sells food, crafs and lunches. In this area it is traditional to eat soups for lunch so it is quite commonplace to see several similar businesses but her micro business is the prefered one. Her mother began it 20 years ago after having had a wholesale vegetable stand in Barranquilla’s market. She started out with a store which she now leases out and then set up a general store. However, this latter project wasn’t very successful due to high competition so it had to be closed; this was one of her most difficult challenges. In 2005 the high demand for lunches and soups in the sector led to her opening this business in order to sell to her neighbors and to established commercial businesses near her home. It is precisely to strengthen this business that she needs funds because she needs to enlarge it and acquire new chairs and kitchen utensils like pots, dishes and cutlery. (She earns additional income selling woven articles of clothing and purses she makes; she sends them to Medellín, an important city in Colombia, to be sold there). She needs to make improvements to her site; it needs a roof over the entrance so that her food business will be more visible and fresh. This will be the 2nd loan she’s gotten from Fundación Mario Santo Domingo. Since associating herself with FMSD she managed to increase her sales and improve her earnings which means improved living conditions; she has been able to acquire home appliances for her use. Continuing forward, she hopes to organize her lunch point of sale in order to increase her income.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To enlarge the site and acquire new chairs and kitchen utensils like pots, plates and cutlery.

loans.name: Johana Mercedes

texts.es: Johana tiene 30 años de edad. Tiene 1 hijo  y vive con ella y le ayuda en lo que puede con su negocio. Su actividad principal es la venta de mercadería en general. El negocio se encuentra de forma ambulante, por lo que todos los días sale a vender los diferentes productos que tiene. Ella realiza su actividad por pedidos y debido a la calidad de productos que ofrece su negocio cada vez está creciendo más, sus pedidos están aumentando y esto ha hecho que piense en ampliar. Johana es una mujer emprendedora y que toda su vida ha velado por el bienestar de los suyos. El financiamiento que solicita es para la compra de materia prima.
texts.en:
30-year old Johana has one son who lives with her and helps with the business in whatever way he can. Johana sells general merchandise--every day she goes into the streets to sell whatever products she has. She takes orders, and because of the quality of her products, her business is continually growing and the number of orders increasing. This has made her think of expanding the business. Johana is an enterprising woman, and throughout her life she has watched out for her family. The loan she is asking for is to buy merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Maria Selene

texts.es: Maria Selene tiene 45 años de edad, tiene 2 hijos a su cargo. por lo que su actividad económica es brindar el servicio de costura hace mas de 13 años que se dedica a este negocio, pues siempre se ha preocupado por mejorar la condición de su familia, ella se ha caracterizado por ser una persona luchadora  Maria Selene elabora: sacos de vestir, vestidos de novia, trajes, pantalones. Pero actualmente solicita este financiamiento para la compra de materia prima que es necesaria para su negocio. el deseo es de ella es mantener este negocio activo.
texts.en:
Maria Selene is 45 years old and cares for her 2 children. She makes a living by providing tailoring services. She has been in this business for more than 13 years She has always been concerned with improving her family’s status. Characterized as a fighter, Maria Selene manufactures: jackets, wedding dresses, suits, and trousers. She is currently seeking financing for the purchase of raw materials necessary for her business. Her desire is to maintain this active business.

Translated from Spanish by Dina Bach, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase raw materials

loans.name: Teresa

texts.es:
Teresa es soltera, tuvo 9 hijos de los cuales 1 vive con ella que esta estudiando, Teresa hace algunos meses vendía frutas y verduras en el mercado Señor de Arequipa, actividad que dejo de realizar porque esta ayudando a su hija en la crianza de su pequeño hijo, actualmente vende chicha a los trabajadores del taller de su hija, actividad que realiza todos los días. 
Teresa pertenece al Banco Comunal Suni que significa Abundante en quechua y necesita un préstamo de 1500 soles que será invertido en la compra de azúcar, maíz.
Teresa sueña con que sus hijos tengan un trabajo estable y prosperen.
texts.en:
Teresa is single. She had 9 children one of whom is a student and still lives with her. A few months ago Teresa was a fruit and vegetable merchant in the Señor de Arequipa market. However, she had to stop doing this work because she had to help her daughter raise her small son. She currently sells chicha (alcoholic beverage made from fermented corn) to the employees in her daughter’s workshop every day. Teresa is a member of the Suni, which means Abundant in Quechua, communal bank. She needs 1500 soles to buy sugar and corn. Teresa dreams with her children having stable jobs and that they prosper.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sugar and corn.

loans.name: Hipolita

texts.es:
Hipólita es separada y tiene 3 hijos, vive en la casa de su hermana y su mayor deseo es tener casa propia, Hipólita viaja a diferentes ferias de la región 2 veces por semana en donde compra quesos, animales, productos que vende en la ciudad de Ayacucho. Además Hipólita vende golosinas de manera ambulatoria en las diferentes fiestas sociales y patronales, actividad que realiza durante toda la noche,
Hipólita necesita un préstamo de 2000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de quesos y carneros.
Hipólita sueña con educar a sus hijos para que sean profesionales y tener un negocio estable.
texts.en:
Hipólita is separated and has three children; she lives in her sister’s house and her greatest wish is to have a house of her own. Hipólita goes to the various regional farmers markets to buy cheese and farm animals that she brings back to the city of Ayacucho to sell. In addition, Hipólita is also an itinerant sweets vendor at various social and patron saint day festivities, an activity she’s involved in all night. She needs a 2000 sol loan to buy cheese and lambs. Hipólita dreams with having a stable business and with educating her children so that they become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cheeses and lambs.

loans.name: Antonia

texts.es:
Antonia pertenece al Banco Comunal Suni que significa Abundante en quechua.
Antonia es casada y tiene 2 hijos, Antonia tiene una tienda en su casa en donD. venD. abarrotes en general, además Antonia junto a su esposo venden cerveza al por mayor, producto que reparte en diferentes lugares D. la ciudad y comunidades. Su préstamo será invertido en la compra D. arroz y azúcar.
Antonia sueña con construir un local en el terreno que tiene para implementar una polleria y el menor D. sus hijos culmine sus estudios.
texts.en:
Antonia is a member of the Suni, which means Abundant in Quechua, communal bank. She’s married and has two children. Antonia has a grocery store in her home. In addition, she and her husband are beer wholesalers; they distribute beer to various parts of the city and to other communities. She will use the loan to buy rice and sugar. Antonia’s dreams are to build on a lot she owns to set up a poultry shop and that her youngest son completes is schooling.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice and sugar.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.es: Nancy es viuda y tiene 4 hijos, Nancy tiene un taller de pintura y fibra en un local alquilado, actividad que realiza con la ayuda de un personal, Nancy se encarga de la administración, además tiene una pequeña tienda en el mismo local en donde vende bebidas. Su préstamo será invertido en la compra de pinturas. Lo que mas le agrada de su Banco Comunal son las capacitaciones que recibe. Nancy sueña con ampliar su taller y que todos sus hijos sean profesionales.
texts.en:
Nancy is a widow with four children. She runs a paint and body shop in a rented locale; she employs staff to help her with the work. Nancy runs the business. She also has a small place where she sells beverages. She will use the funds to buy paint. What she enjoys the most about her communal bank is the training sessions she gets.
