loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Mrs. Chea V. is 32 years old and a resident of Kompong Tom Province, where she operates a small business raising a few pigs for income. Beyond this, she has a life partner in her husband, who is hired by people to plow farmland for a fee. She was married many years, but has no children yet. Chea V. is a hard-working woman who never wastes time in order to earn money to ensure that the family has a better life. Chea V. is taking out her first loan to support her pig raising activity.

loans.use: To support her pig raising activity.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy L. is a 50-year-old widow who supports her family by her general store and rice retailing business. She lives in Brgy Mahilum, Calatrava, Negros Occidental, with her four children aged 15 to 37 years old. One of her children has their own family while the other three children are currently in school.
Lucy has been a member of Kiva partner, NWTF-Project Dungganon, since 1990 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and rice retailing business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 10,000 PHP.
Lucy is now borrowing 20,000 PHP to continue her general store and rice retailing business. This will be her 17th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 20,000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Lucy aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure its future wellbeing by following the 'Dungganon' way.

About NWTF
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means 'honorable'). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them 'Dungganon' – a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of the community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: As additonal working capital

loans.name: Chhin

texts.en: C. is a widowed mother blessed with two school-aged children. She currently lives with her elderly mother who stays at home to feed a few pigs for a profit. C., age 32, has a suitable job working in the garment industry. C. has seen that the pig-raising trade is a profitable one for the family, so she would like to request a loan in order to buy extra piglets to raise.

loans.use: To buy extra piglets.

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma C. is a 35-year-old married woman who lives in Juan Luna St., Bais City, Negros Oriental. She earns her living by her general store, eatery and rice retailing business. Gemma’s 40-year-old husband, Ceasar, helps his wife in managing the business. Their four children, currently all in school, help their parents in the business as part of their daily chores.
Gemma joined Kiva partner, NWTF-Project Dungganon, in 2008 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life for their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase the family income by engaging in her general store, eatery and rice retailing business. Now she earns an average monthly income of 21,700 PHP from her business activities.
Gemma is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of 17,500 PHP was used to fund operations of her general store, eatery and rice retailing business, which had a positive impact in both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is taking her fifth loan, for 19,500 PHP, which she intends to use for her general store, eatery and rice retailing business. Gemma is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means 'honorable'). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them 'Dungganon' – a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of the community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: As additional working capital

loans.name: Tim

texts.en: Mr. Tim H. is 41 years old and a married man. His wife, who appears in the photo, is a local cultivator. This couple has seven children, four of whom are now married and have already established their own family homes, while the other three are single. Tim H. is currently able to generate a great income by raising pigs and crops. Since he doesn’t have a vehicle for his transportation needs, he normally travels to anywhere by hiring a taxi. Because he wants to cut down this expense, Tim H. has requested a loan of $700 to be used to purchase a second-hand motorcycle to provide transportation for his family.

loans.use: To purchase a second-hand motorcycle.

loans.name: Van

texts.en: Mrs. Van T. is a 42-year-old married woman and mother. She has a rental shop inside the local market where she sells food and earns an adequate amount to help with her family’s financial problems. She has another financial earner in her husband who has the skill of making furniture by hand. This couple helps each other in order to generate money to support their four school-aged children. Van T. is taking out a loan to purchase more raw materials for her husband to produce sets of furniture to sell.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials.

loans.name: Ten

texts.en: N., 57, lives in the rural area of Kompong Tom Province, where she owns a small business, the main activity of which is to weave baskets for sale. She married years ago and has four children, two of whom are now married and the remaining two are going to school. Her husband is the main provider who works producing furniture to earn a living. N. is looking for a loan for her husband to increase the capital of his furniture-making trade.

loans.use: To increase business capital.

loans.name: Dim

texts.en:
Dim T. is 28 years old and resides in Kompong Tom Province, Cambodia, where she makes an income by raising crops on her farm.  She has a partner in her husband who appears in the photo here. He always assists her in growing various crops.  This couple has two kids who attend school.

As the potato-growing season is approaching, Dim T. is requesting a loan amount of $300 from HKL, a Kiva field partner. She will use the loan to grow a better crop of potatoes.

loans.use: To grow a better crop of potatoes.

loans.name: Kalagala Development Group, Mpigi

texts.en:
M. Clement, a 37-year-old married father of four, was at first a farmer before he decided to venture into the car and motorcycle repair business in Kalagala, Mpigi. He has a decade-long track record in the car repair business.

This down-to-earth, persuasive and focused entrepreneur attributes his business’s decade-long longevity to his hard work and clearly drawn out business objectives. In a month, Clement says he makes profits in the range of 100,000 to 200,000 Ugandan shillings. He supplements these profits by also doing some commercial farming.

With this loan, Clement says, he is bent on buying more seeds for his farming gardens and also paying his farm workers.

loans.use: To buy seeds for his gardens and pay his farm workers

loans.name: Baraka Office Group

texts.fr:
Ekanga L. est entrepreneur, vendeuse grossiste des braises, elle lève sa main sur la photo,vice présidente  du groupe de crédit Baraka Office, âgée de 42 ans, veuve, mère de  6 enfants dont tous étudient. Sa fille ainée est en première licence à l’université, et les restes sont encore à l’école secondaire et primaire. Son mari est décède vers les années 2000 suite a une longue maladie du VIH SIDA. Ekanga L. réside dans le quartier Murara, commune de Karisimbi, elle a un dépôt des braises dans le secteur Birere. En outre pour maximiser ses revenus, elle vent également d’huile de palme en gros au marché  de KIBABI. Ekanga L. a commence son business avec son fonds propres  au tour des années 2002, avant l’éruption du volcan Nyiragongo, qui avait détruit complètement la vie économique de la ville de Goma. Elle vendait des beignets, avec un capital de valeur de 12,5$. Et cela après la mort de son mari.
Vue la charge de familiale et la vie seule, elle a évolué difficilement. Cependant elle a bénéficié de premier crédit  de l’IMF Hekima en 2004. De la, elle a retrouvé un équilibre social et  économique. Dit-elle, Ekanga L. a déjà réalisé plusieurs projets familiaux (achat d’une parcelle). Si Dieu la prête vie, Ekanga L. reste ambitieuse, malgré son statut de veuve, de pouvoir construire une maison pour ses enfants. Avec  le crédit  de  l’IMF Hekima, la veuve Ekanga L.  souhaite augmenter son chiffre d’affaire en achetant 10 sacs des braises (affecte au business de braise) et 5 fus d’huile (localement appelés «Kafindondo». Ekanga L. explique le défi majeur de son activité de vente braises est lié aux multiples pillages au long de la route par des assaillants ,qui restent dans le parc national de Virunga, a l’Est de la RDC et rebelles Hutu rwandais de FDLR. A cela s’ajoute les tracasseries policières et administratives  surtout comme l’Etat a déjà pris de mesures pénales aux soit disant destructeurs de l’environnement (vendeurs de bois de parc national). Pour l’activité de vente d’huile  parfois elle achète un stock  d’huile pourries, des mauvaises qualités, qui a déjà perdue toute la saveur, étant donné que cette huile est produite en technologie locale artisanale dans la province de Kindu-Maniema et dans le grand Nord de Kivu, vers Beni, Mangina, et conservée parfois dans de bidons salles ou des emballages en caoutchouc fragile, etc.  Cela contraint à connaitre une perte énorme.
La veuve Ekanga L.  remercie l’IMF Hekima pour  les crédits  qu’elle reçoit sans aucune garantie matérielle car grâce à ces crédits, elle parvient à subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants orphelins. Le groupe baraka office est composé de 8 femmes.
texts.en:
Ekanga L. is a businesswoman who sells charcoal wholesale. She is the one raising her hand in the photo and is vice-president of the loan group Baraka Office. She is 42, a widow and mother of six children, all enrolled in school. Her eldest daughter is in the first year at university, and the others are in secondary or primary school. Her husband died after a long illness, around the year 2000, of HIV AIDS. Ekanga L. lives in the Murara neighborhood, township of Karisimbi, and she has a charcoal depot in the Birere district. Moreover, in order to maximize her income, she also sells palm oil wholesale in the market of KIBABI. Ekanga L. began her business with her own funds around 2002, before the eruption of the Nyiragongo volcano, which completely destroyed the economic life of the town of Goma. She was selling fritters with a working capital of $12.50. And all this after her husband's death. In view of her family responsibilities and living alone, she was just scraping by. However, in 2004, she received a first loan from the MFI Hekima. From then on, she was able to reestablish her social and economic equilibrium. Ekanga L. has already managed to achieve some family goals, notably the purchase of a plot of land. If God grants her long life, Ekanga L. intends to continue to be ambitious enough, despite being a widow, to build a house for her children. With the loan from Hekima, widow Ekanga L. hopes to grow her sales by buying 10 sacks of charcoal (for her charcoal business) and 5 barrels of oil (locally known as «Kafindondo».) Ekanga L. says that the major challenge to her charcoal business is the multiple attacks along the route carried out by outlaws who are hiding in the Virunga National Park, in the east of the DRC, and Rwandan Hutu rebels from the FDLR. Also the police and administrators make difficulties, especially since the State has threatened to bring to justice those they say are destroying the environment (people who sell wood from the national park). As for her oil sales business, she sometimes buys a load of spoiled oil or poor quality oil which has lost all its flavor, since this oil is produced by local artisans in the province of Kindu-Maniema and way up north near Lake Kivu, around Beni, or Mangina, and sometimes stored in dirty jerrycans or rubber containers that are fragile, etc. This can cause her an enormous loss. Widow Ekanga L. would like to thank the MFI Hekima for the loans that she receives without collateral since it is thanks to these loans that she is managing to support her orphaned children. The Baraka Office group is composed of eight women.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: 10 sacks of charcoal and 5 barrels of oil (locally known as «Kafindondo»)

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Sen

texts.en:
Sen S. is 39 years old and has been selling a few fresh fish in and around the community for more than nine years. She sells fish that she buys from her wholesale supplier and from other fishermen. She is married to Visal, 43, who has a great deal of experience in building stone and wooden houses from which he earns a living. 

Sen S. has given birth to two kids, both of whom are no longer in school and are now unemployed. She wants to encourage both of her children to have suitable jobs as vehicle repairmen, but she doesn’t have money yet to do so. Therefore, Sen S. decided to request a loan to buy tools for her children to begin providing that service.

loans.use: To buy tools for vehicle repair.

loans.name: Tusubira Women's Group 1, Lugazi

texts.en:
Her salon business is a beehive of activity. To all appearances, there is an outward appreciation written on the faces of her customers.

For 38-year-old, enterprising, Zilibagwa P. the last ten years have been eventful in terms of the checkered experiences she has gone through to get where she is now. Through the course of many of these experiences before she started this business, P., a housewife then, found herself at a constant wits end as she struggled to fully provide for her family’s needs. With this business opening, however, circumstances have improved a great deal. Her family's financial status quo has also improved a great deal.

At present, P. makes profits totaling up to 150,000 shillings a week. This is a far cry from, and in contrast to, when she was a housewife when odds seemed to be stacked against her. With a stable business running, she also rationalized that eking out side-profits constructing and running a rental and retail shop business where she sells blankets and mattresses, would not be a bad proposition.

P. has managed to reconcile all her duties well and her businesses are all driving a roaring trade. With this loan, she wants to buy more salon equipment and also improve her rental business.

loans.use: To purchase more salon equipment and also improve her rental business

loans.name: Elmina Silvestre

texts.pt:
Elmina Silvestre M. nasceu no Distrito de Marracuene, Província de Maputo, sul de Moçambique, tem 46 anos de idade casada e mãe de um filho de 30 anos de idade, pois não conseguiu mais conceber, o mesmo filho encontra se desempregado do momento. Elmina astudou até 6ª classe, teve que interroper devido a gravidez precoce. Vive na casa própria e responsabiliza se pelos seus pais que vivem em Marracuene enviando lhes uma sexta básica no valor de 800.00mt mensalmente.
	
Elmina é convidada pela tia para viver em Namaacha na Fronteira de Swazilândia, após sua chegada ela continua com os estudos e quando frequentava a 6ª classe ficou gravida. Anos depois começa a fazer mukero (venda de produtos contra bandeada )  na Fronteira da Swazilândia, mas porque o trabalho é muito pesado ela opta em iniciar com a venda de produtos de primeira necessidade na sua residência. Com o fundo colectado, consegue construir uma pequena loja na sua residência. Tem como melhores produtos  o(arroz e açucar  compra o saco  por 85000mtx4 e 1.800.00mtx2) vende por 1.250.00mtx4 e 2050mtx2) tem receita mensal de 4.000.00mt e consegue poupar  1.000.00mt  mensalmente,conta com ajuda do marido que trabalha no Governo como Secretario do bairro.

Este é o seu terceiro empréstimo na HLUVUKU-ADSEMA e Kiva, todos foram no valor de 10.000,para a compra de produtos (arroz, feijão, açúcar e outros) para aumentar a quantidade da mercadoria para a sua loja. Esta confiante que vai reembolsar antes do prazo. Futuramente pretente adiquirir mais empréstimo e construir uma loja grande para satisfazer a sua clientela.
texts.en:
Elmina Silvestre M. was born in Marracuene District, Maputo Province in southern Mozambique. She is a 46-year-old married woman, and she has one son who is 30 years old. She was unable to have any more children, and her son is currently unemployed. Elmina finished sixth grade but had to interrupt her studies because of an early pregnancy. She lives in her own house and takes care of her parents, who live in Marracuene, by sending them 800 meticais' worth of food and household goods every month. Elmina was invited by her aunt to come live in Namaacha, which is on the border with Swaziland. After her arrival, she continued with her studies, and when she was in sixth grade she became pregnant. Some years later, she began to work in mukero (sale of contraband goods) on the Swaziland border, but because the work was very hard, she decided to begin selling basic goods from her home. With her savings she built a small store in her home. Her best products are rice and sugar, which she buys by the sack for 850 meticais per four sacks and 1800 meticais per two sacks, respectively. She sells them for 1,250 meticais per four sacks and 2,050 meticais per two sacks. Elmina manages to save 1,000 meticais per month. She counts on the help of her husband, who works in government as the neighborhood Secretary. This is Elmina's third loan with Hluvuku-Adsema and Kiva. The others were for 10,000 meticais each, and were used to purchase products (rice, beans, sugar and other items) to increase the inventory of her store. She is confident that she will pay back the loan ahead of schedule. In the future, she intends to apply for more loans and build a large store to meet her customers' needs.

Translated from Portuguese by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of rice, beans, sugar, etc.

loans.name: Saven

texts.en: Mrs. Saven V., 48 years old, lives in Dei Edth Kaoh Phos village in Kandal province. She is a cake seller while her husband, Mr. Mao Sam, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate vegetables. Mrs. Saven V. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticides to support her husband's farming. Besides working on his own farm, Mr. Mao Sam is a farm laborer so that he can receive a small salary to support his family. This couple has three children, who all are students in the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticides

loans.name: Kaliba Development Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
38-year-old M. Solomy is a married woman with three children. For the last seven years she has been plying her business selling new clothes in Lugazi town. With it, she has been able to provide for all her children.

Solomy’s future prospects, too, are not looking bad given the 300,000 shillings she makes in a week. By implication, she has enough financial clout to ensure her business’s longevity. With this loan, she wants to make purchases of new clothes that she will sell to her increasing clientele.

Solomy is a business lady, indeed! She started her business from the little savings she had made as a housewife but, due to her determination and hard work, she is where she is now.

loans.use: The purchase more new clothes to sell

loans.name: Ith

texts.en: Mrs. Ith C. is 27 years old and lives in Sdau Kanlaeng-ID village in Kandal province. She fishes to earn a small income to support her family. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more fish. Mrs. Ith C. is a widow with a child who attends the local school.

loans.use: To buy more fish

loans.name: Sreipov

texts.en: Mrs. Sreipov L. is 37 years old and lives in Boeng K’aek village in Kandal province.She earns a small income to support her family by selling fried bananas and potatoes. Mrs. Sreipov L. is requesting a loan to purchase a motorbike to transport her products for resale. She is a widow with two children; they are both students in the local school and support their mother with her business.

loans.use: to purchase a motorbike to transport her products for resale

loans.name: Yorn

texts.en: Mr. Yorn C. is 31 years old and lives in Svay village in Kandal province. He is a laborer in a garment factory and his wife, Mrs. Sambath Choi, is a seamstress in a garment factory. With both positions, they earn a small income to support their family. In order to maintain his job, Mr. Yorn C. decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorbike for transportation. This couple has two children; one attends the local school while the youngest one is 5 years old. His wife is in the picture with him.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Sokhhim

texts.en: Mr. Sokhhim K. is a 32-year-old married man who lives in Preaek Pang village, Kandal province. He is a vegetable seller while his wife, Mrs. Mom Chea, is a pork rice seller. With both businesses, they earn a small income to support their family. Since vegetable selling is going well, Mr. Sokhhim K. wants to expand it, so he decided to ask for a loan to buy more vegetables. This couple has two children, who are too young to study or work. His wife is in the picture with him.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables

loans.name: Sokha

texts.en: Mrs. Sokha S. is a 29-year-old married woman who lives in Angk village, Kandal province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice while her husband, Mr. Meng Kong, earns a small income as a cow middleman to support his family. To maintain her farming crops, Mrs. Sokha S. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and gasoline. This couple has four children; two are students in the local school while the other two are too young to study or work. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and gasoline

loans.name: Toch

texts.en: Mrs. Toch L. is a 28-year-old married woman who lives in Prek Thmey village in Kandal province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to grow crops. Mrs. Toch L. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticides and gasoline to support her farming crops. Her husband, Mr. Sophann Phan, is a laborer in a garment factory where he receives a small salary to support his family. This couple has a child who is 7 years old.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticides and gasoline

loans.name: Thoeurn

texts.en: Mrs. Thoeurn E. is 51 years old and lives in Preaek Thei village in Kandal province. She is a farmer who rents a piece of land to cultivate rice. Mrs. Thoeurn E. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticides and gasoline to support her farming crop. Besides working on her land, she is also a farm laborer so that she can earn a small salary to support her family. Mrs. Thoeurn E. is a widow with four children; three are laborers and one is a student in the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticides and gasoline

loans.name: Katusenvule Development Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
When you clock up fifty years, many people, especially in Africa, write you off as ineffectual and, even worse, as a person of straw. For one to fight this stereotype, requires lots of summoned-up courage and resolve.

50-year-old K. Ronah banked on the above to take root in her retail shop in Buloba, Lugazi. She has been a stickler for hard work for the last eight years since her business has been operational. Because of this she has made lots of strides in effectively providing for her family’s welfare on the steady profits she has been making. In a week, she says she makes profits that amount to 30,000 shillings.

Ronah started off her business with savings from her farming business which is now on a small scale. With this loan, she says she wants to buy more general merchandise retail items like soap and sugar for her store.

loans.use: To purchase more general merchandise like soap and sugar for her store

loans.name: Mean

texts.en: Mr. Mean M. is 62 years old and lives in Vihear village, Kandal province. He is a farmer who owns 1.30-hectares of land to cultivate rice for a living. Mr. Mean M. decided to ask for a loan to buy a water machine to support his farm crop. Besides farming, he also has a store which he rents to someone having a party or wedding ceremony. His wife, Mrs. Ly Uy, stays at home and cooks for the family. This couple has six children: one is a seamstress in a garment factory, one is a farmer who supports his father's farming, two are students in the local school and the other two are married. His wife is in the picture with him.

loans.use: to buy a water machine

loans.name: Lela Group

texts.en:
Betty D., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Lela. She is 46 years old, married, and has five children who range from 13 to 21 years old. She was able to attend school only through 12th grade. She cares for two siblings. All of her children attend school.

For a year, she has been selling charcoal and oil in the ELWA Community outside of Monrovia, Liberia. She describes herself as a God-fearing woman. She says customers get attracted to her business because she she sells good oil and charcoal.

She plans to use her 6,000 LRD portion of this 30,000 LRD group loan to buy more charcoal and oil. 
 
Her goal is to grow her business, build a shop and to be able to help other members of her family.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and oil.

loans.name: Sararn

texts.en: Mrs. Sararn C. is 38 years old and lives in Angk village in Kandal province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to grow crops. Her husband, Mr. Vanna Song, is a construction worker who earns a small income to support his family. Since her husband's workplace is far from the house, Mrs. Sararn C. decided to ask for a loan to purchase a motorcycle for transportation. This couple has six children: five attend the local school and help their mother farm and the youngest one is 3 years old. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle

loans.name: Salorn

texts.en: Mrs. Salorn V. is a 30-year-old married woman who lives in Lvea Sa Kandal village in Kandal province. She is a fish seller and her husband, Mr. Thorn Penh, is a cow middleman. With both businesses, they can earn a small income to support their family. Mrs. Salorn V. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow to support her husband's business. This couple has four children: three are students in the local school while the youngest one is 2 years old. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Blessing Children Group

texts.en:
Alfred W., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Blessing Children. He is 52 years old, divorced, and has two children, 18 and 23 years old. He was able to attend school only through 7th grade due to financial difficulties. He also cares for three siblings. All of the children are attending school.

For four years, he has been selling creme, soap, hair grease, perfume etc. in West point Market, Monrovia, Liberia.  He plans to use his 6,000 LRD portion of this 30,000 LRD group loan to buy more creme, soap, hair grease, perfume etc. to sell.  His dream is to expand his business.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Isaiah is inset at lower right because he was absent during the group interview.

loans.use: To buy more creme, soap, hair grease, perfume etc.

loans.name: Catharine

texts.en:
Catharine is 51 years old. She is married and has seven children between the ages of 14 and 30 years old. Four of the children are currently attending school.

She is a farmer from Litein town in Rift Valley Kenya. She has been farming for 20 years and has employed one person from the community. Her products are pineapples, tea and milk which she sells to the local market. She also operates a boutique in the same area. Her biggest challenge in farming is lack of market for her products and inconsistency in the milk prices.

She has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo for 70,000 KES to purchase a dairy cow. This loan will increase the income for the family and therefore ease the burden of paying school fees and other expenses. In five years time, she hopes to have purchased more quality cows that will increase the production of milk and to buy a vehicle to aid in transporting her products to the market.

Catharine is interested in more Juhudi loans because it has improved her standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is 32 years old. She is married and has no children. She is a farmer from Litein town in Rift Valley Kenya. Joyce has been farming for eight years and has one employee. Her products are milk, tea and pineapples which she sells to the local market.

Her major challenges in farming are the high cost of medicine for her dairy cows when they get sick and lack of sufficient market for her milk and pineapples.

She has successfully completed a previous loan from Juhudi Kilimo for 45,000 KES which she used to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She has requested this loan from Juhudi for 50,000 KES to purchase another dairy cow. This loan will enable her acquire a quality dairy cow that will produce enough milk for sale and hence earn her enough income.

In the future she intends to improve the quality of her breed for better milk production and to open a shop as well.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Phineas

texts.en:
Phineas is 40 years old. He is married with two children, age 6 and 13 years old. Both of the children are currently attending school.

He is a farmer from Nkubu town in Eastern Kenya. He has been farming for fifteen years and his products are bananas and cereals which he sells to the local market. He also operates a hotel business and a salon in the same area. His major challenge in farming is insufficient finances for expansion and an insufficient supply of water.

He recently completed a previous loan from Juhudi Kilimo for 45,000 KES. He has requested this loan from Juhudi for 60,000 KES to purchase farm supplies and to install a water system to improve his banana plantation. The extra income from this loan will enable him to pay school fees for his children and to build a decent home for his family.

In the future he would like to purchase an extra two acres of land to increase his banana plantation.

He says Juhudi Kilimo has made him realize that farming is a business like any other.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies and install a water system.

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is 57 years old. He is married and has three children, age 22, 24 and 26 years old. One of his children is still attending school.

He is a farmer from Eastern Kenya near Nkubu town. He has been farming for ten years and his products are milk, pawpaw, bananas and mangoes that he sells to the local market. He also owns some rental houses in the same area. His biggest challenges in farming are lack of enough finances for expansion, poor infrastructure and low prices for his farm produce.

He has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo for 40,000 KES to construct a water tank to improve his banana plantation. The extra income from this loan will enable him to pay school fees for his children and to improve his family's standard of living. In the future, he hopes to be selling his farm produce to international markets and to acquire at least three high yielding milk cows.

He says that Juhudi Kilimo is the best organization for small scale farmers.

loans.use: To construct a water tank.

loans.name: Lucia Isac

texts.pt:
Lucia Isac N. nasceu na cidade de Maputo, vive maritalmente é mãe de 3 filhos com idades compriendidas entre os 19 aos 25 anos. Duas mais velhas estão empregadas na educação somente o mais novo é que vai a escola. Vive na casa própria com sua familia e não responsabiliza se por niguem.  

Lúcia quando frequentava a 6ª classe fica grávida e interrompe os estudos, Após o parto Lúcia contínua a viver em casa dos progenitores estes que cuidaram dela nos momentos mais difíceis da sua vida. Anos depois ela retoma os seus estudos e consegue fazer a 10ª classe, de seguida faz o curso de professorado no Distrito de Namaacha na fronteira da Suazilândia. 

Abandonou o curso depois de se juntar com seu actual esposo, o mesmo que lhe deu um valor para iniciar com seu próprio negócio de venda de potes adquiridas em Maputo e revendidas na Suazilândia, actividade que pratica ate então, nas quartas e sábados no mercado informal a céu aberto. Nesta actividade consegue um rendimento de cerca de 6.000.00mt por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa ainda consegue poupar algum com ajuda da sua machamba de hortícolas (alface e couve) que possui no quintal da sua casa.

Este é o sétimo empréstimo de Lúcia na Hluvuku e segundo com Kiva. Os seis primeiros de (5.000.00mt, 5.000.00mt, 12.000.00mt, 10.000.00mt, 10.000.00mt e 10.000.00mt) foram usados para aumentar a quantidade da sua mercadoria, valores que pagou sem nenhum problema e solicita este de 12.000.00mt para o mesmo fim. Esta confiante que vai pagar antes do tempo determinado e pedir um novo empréstimo para concluir a sua obra.
texts.en:
Lúcia Isac N. was born in the city of Maputo. She is married and has three children between the ages of 19 and 25. The two eldest have jobs in education, and only the youngest still goes to school. Lúcia lives in her own house with her family and does not support anyone else. Lúcia became pregnant in sixth grade and quit school. After the birth of her child, Lúcia continued to live in her parents' house, and they took care of her during the most difficult time of her life. Some years later, she returned to school and finished tenth grade. After that, she immediately took a teaching course in Namaacha District, which is on the border with Swaziland. She quit the class when she got together with her current husband, who gave her the money to start her own business selling pots which she buys in Maputo and resells in Swaziland. She still does this work on Wednesdays and Saturdays at the open-air market. Lúcia earns about 6,000 meticais per month, which she uses for household expenses. She also manages to save some money with the help of the vegetable garden in her yard, where she grows lettuce and cabbage. This is Lúcia's seventh loan with Hluvuku and her second with Kiva. The first six loans were for 5,000 meticais, 5,000 meticais, 12,000 meticais, 10,000 meticais, 10,000 meticais and 10,000 meticais. They were used to increase her inventory, and she paid them back with no problems. She is now asking for 12,000 meticais for the same purpose. Lúcia is confident that she will pay off this loan ahead of schedule and ask for another loan for a construction project.

Translated from Portuguese by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of pots, casserole dishes, etc.

loans.name: Felix Antonio

texts.pt:
Felix Antonio M., nasceu em Namaacha, Província de Maputo, vizinho com reino da suazilândia, vive maritalmente é pai de uma filha de 2 anos não vai a escola. Fez a 10ª classe não conseguiu continuar porque teve que trabalhar muito cedo devido a falta de condições. Vive na casa do seu tio (dependências) e não responsabiliza se por ninguém. 


Nunca saiu do Distrito. Devido a falta de condições dos seus progenitores seu tio convida lhe para viver com ele, so que no mesmo ano este é transferido para Maputo deixando lhe com a casa. Consegue aranjar um emprego nas Bombas da Total como Bombeiro auferindo salario de 2.250.00mt mensalmente que aplica nas dispesas da casa e consegue poupar 500.00mt através do xitique (sistema tradicional de poupança rotativa).

Na tentativa de aumentar a renda familiar solicita emprestimo na hluvuku e kiva para compra e venda de roupas usadas, actividade que já vinha praticando com a ajuda da sua mulher. Tem comprado uma média de 2 fardos  gastando 8.000.00mt e tem como melhor peça o fardo de camisola tendo de lucro 3.000.00mt


Este é o primeiro empréstimo de Felix na Hluvuku e Kiva no valor de 12.000.00mt com o qual sera usado para comprar fardos de roupas usadas. Esta confiante que vai pagar antes do tempo previsto e pedir outro empréstimo para construção da sua própria casa e sair  casa do tio.
texts.en:
Felix Antonio M. was born in the district of Namaacha, in the province of Maputo close to the border with Swaziland. He is married, and has a 2-year-old daughter who is not yet in school. Felix only finished 10th grade. He didn't continue with his studies because he had to begin working due to his family’s lack of financial resources. He lives in his uncle’s house and is not financially responsible for anyone beyond his immediate family. Felix has always lived in Namaacha. Due to his parents’ lack of financial resources, his uncle invited Felix to live with him. That same year, his uncle was transferred to Maputo, leaving Felix with the house. Felix managed to get a job as a plumber with a monthly salary of 2250 meticais. He uses this income to cover household expenses and also saves 500 meticais each month through Xitique, a traditional system of rotating savings. In an effort to increase his family’s income, Felix is asking for a loan through Hluvuku and Kiva to buy used clothing for resale. This is an enterprise that he’s already undertaken with the help of his wife. On average he buys 2 packs for 8000 meticais; the best type for him is a pack of nightclothes, with which he can make a profit of 3000 meticais. This is Felix’s first loan with Hluvuku and Kiva, for 12,000 meticais. He will use the money to buy packs of used clothing. He is confident that he will be able to repay the loan even earlier than required so that he can request another loan to build his own house, and move out of his uncle’s house.

Translated from Portuguese by Catherine Fountain, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of packs of used clothing

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase an additional part for a tractor

loans.name: Anne

texts.en:
Anne is 39 years old. She is married and has 4 children aged between 3 and 13 years old. All of the children are currently attending school.

She is a farmer from Western Kenya near Kitale town. She has been farming for 12 years and has one employee. Her products are maize, milk, beans and eggs which she sells to the local market. Anne is also a tailor. Her biggest challenge in farming is the fluctuation in market prices and poultry diseases, which results to great losses.

Anne has a good record with Juhudi Kilimo after she successfully completed a previous loan of Kes.30,000. She has requested this loan for Kes.50,000 to expand her poultry project. The extra income from this loan will boost her other sources of income hence their needs will be well taken care of.

She is hoping that the project will have expanded in 5 years time and she will be able to meet her expenses.
She is grateful to Juhudi because she has been empowered financially.

loans.use: To expand her poultry project.

loans.name: Alice

texts.pt:
Alice T. nasceu no distrito de Namaacha na Fronteira da Swazilândia é viúva e mãe de 4 filhos com idades compriendidas entre os 9 aos 26 anos de idade, os três mais novos é que vão a escola. Vive na casa propria e não sustenta mais ninguém.

Alice após concluir o Ensino Primário é transferida para Sede do Distrito de Namaacha que dista 25km da localidade de Goba onde ela nasceu. Continua com os seus estudos e faz 7ª classe, fica gravida e passa a viver com seu marido que era um grande comerciante abandonando assim a escola. Anos depois o seu marido perde a vida por motivo de doênça e a vida fica dificil, então ela consegue aranjar um emprego na cidade capital Maputo como empregada doméstica e trabalha durante 2 anos onde recebia 2.300.00mt. 
Mas teve que abandonar pois vivia longe dos seus filhos e regressa novamente a Namaacha onde inicia seu próprio negócio de venda de pães e rebuçados no quintal da sua casa. 

Na tentativa de aumentar o volume do seu negócio aproxima se a Hluvuku solicitando um empréstimo para reforçar a actividade da criaçao de pintos que já iniciara com os lucrus obtidos no emprestimo passado.Tem criado uma média de 2 caixas em sua casa gastando 15.000.00mt em cada fase tendo de lucro 6.000.00mt que aplica nas dispesas da casa e ainda consegue poupar cerca de 1.000.00mt por mês.

Este é o segundo empréstimo de Alice na Hluvuku e Kiva no valor de 12.000.00mt com o qual pretende usar para aumentar a quantidade da sua criação, o anterior empréstimo foi no valor de 10.000.00mt e foi usado para dar início de venda de rebuçados. 
Esta confiante que vai pagar sem nenhum problema pois ela conta também com receita de aluguer da sua casa cituada em Boane. Futuramente pretende pedir um novo empréstimo para construir o seu próprio estabelecimento de venda e deixar de vender somente no quintal da sua casa.
texts.en:
Alice T. was born in the district of Namaacha, close to the border with Swaziland. She is a widow and has 4 children who range in age from 9 to 26 years old. The three youngest children are in school. She lives in her own home and is not financially responsible for anyone except her children. After finishing her primary education, Alice was transferred to the district seat of Namaacha, which is 25 kilometers from the town of Goba where she was born. She continued with her studies and finished 7th grade. Then she got pregnant and went to live with her husband, who was an important businessman. This is why she left school. Years later, her husband died after an illness and life became difficult. It was then that she managed to get a job in the capital, Maputo, as a household servant. She held this job for 2 years, receiving a salary of 2300 meticais per month. She had to leave this job because she was living far from her children, and so she returned to Namaacha. There she began her own business selling bread and candy from the yard of her house. In an effort to increase the scope of her business, she has approached Hluvuku to ask for a loan to help her to raise baby chicks. She had already started with this enterprise using the profit she made after getting her previous loan. She has raised on average 2 cartons full during each cycle, costing 15,000 meticais and making a profit of 6000 meticais. She uses this income to cover household expenses and also saves some 1000 meticais each month. This is Alice’s 2nd loan with Hluvuku and Kiva, for the amount of 12000 Meticales. She plans to use the loan to increase the number of chicks she raises. Her previous loan, in the amount of 10,000 meticais, was used to start her sales of candy. Alice is confident that she will have no problems repaying this loan because she also has income from the rental of a house she owns in Boane. In the future she would like to get another loan to build her own store, so that she no longer has to sell from her own yard.

Translated from Portuguese by Catherine Fountain, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of baby chicks for raising

loans.name: Unice

texts.en:
Unice is 50 years old. She is married with 6 children aged between 22 and 33 years old. Her youngest child is currently attending school.

She is a farmer from Western Kenya in Kitale town. She has been farming for 12 years and has one employee. She sells timber, sugarcane, sweet potatoes, honey and vegetables to the local market. She also operates a shop in the same area. She faces the challenge of diseases attacking her dairy cows and lack of enough nappier grass to feed the animals during the dry seasons.

She has requested a loan from Juhudi Kilimo for Kes.31,200 to purchase and feed a dairy cow. This loan will improve his life and that of her family since they will be able to get enough milk for consumption and sale to generate more income. In the future, she would like to build rental houses.

She says that this loan has enabled her to be a dairy farmer and she promises to pay regularly and later make another loan to progress further with her business.

loans.use: To purchase and feed a dairy cow.

loans.name: Lorta Uaquene

texts.pt:
Lorta Uaquene N. nasceu em Inhambane, província do mesmo nome, sul de Moçambique, solteira e mãe de 4 filhos, dos quais 3 perderam a vida um ainda vivo e empregado numa empresa privada. Vive na casa própria com seu filho, nora e seus 3 netos que vão a escola.   

Com 15 anos Lorta inicia seus estudos, faz a 2ª classe do antigo sistema e de seguida esta fica gravida. Fica muito desesperada após a morte dos seus filhos no tempo da guerra, sua irmã convida lhe para morar com ela no Distrito de Namaacha na fronteira da suazilândia, após sua chegada começa a trabalhar como empregada doméstica. 

Com o fundo colectado ela inicia seu próprio negócio e constroi sua casa com o rendimento ganho nos negócios, mas devido aos preparativos do casamento do seu filho ela fica na beira da falência e pede empréstimo a Hluvuku no valor de 8.000.00mt para reforçar o seu negócio. tem vendido 2 vezes por semana quartas e sabados no Mercado Informal onde há intercâmbio de produtos vindo de paises fora tem de lucro 5.000.00mt que gasta nas dispesas da casa e ainda consegue poupar algum.

 Este é o terceiro empréstimo de Lorta na Hluvuku e segundo com Kiva.O primeiro 8.000.00.mt foi usado para reforçar o seu negocio, o segundo de 10.000.00mt foi usado para aumentar a quantidade do seu stock, e este terceiro de 15.000.00mt serao para a mesma finalidade que é a compra de fardo de roupa usada diversa. Esta confiante que vai reembolsar antes do tempo previsto e pedir um novo empréstimo para concluir a casa do seu único filho.
texts.en:
Lorta Uaquene N. was born in the district of Inhambane, in the province of the same name in the south of Mozambique. Lorta is unmarried and had 4 children. Three of her children died, but one still lives and is employed at a private firm. She lives in her own home with her son, her daughter-in-law, and her 3 grandchildren, all of whom attend school. At age 15, Lorta began her studies, and finished the 2nd year of secondary school under the old education system. After this she became pregnant. After her children died during the Mozambican Civil War, she became despondent. Her sister invited Lorta to live with her in the district of Namaacha on the border with Swaziland. After moving there she began to work as a domestic servant. With her earnings, Lorta started her own business, and then built a house with the profit from that enterprise. However, due to expenses related to her son’s wedding she is close to bankruptcy. For this reason she is asking for a loan in the amount of 8000 meticais to shore up her business. She works two days a week, Wednesdays and Saturdays, selling at an unofficial market where people trade in imported goods. She earns about 5000 meticais per month and uses this income to cover household expenses. She also saves some each month. This is Lorta’s 3rd loan with Hluvuku and her 2nd with Kiva. The first loan, in the amount of 8000 meticais, was used to help shore up her business. The second, in the amount of 10,000 meticais, was used to increase her stock of merchandise. This third loan, for 15,000 meticais, will be used for the same purpose, to buy packs of used clothing for resale. Lorta is confident that she will repay this loan even sooner than required so that she can get another loan to finish building a house for her son.

Translated from Portuguese by Catherine Fountain, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of packs of used clothing

loans.name: Andrew

texts.en:
Andrew is 39 years. He is married and has 6 children aged between 9 months and 18 years old. Four of the children are currently attending school.

He is a farmer from Western Kenya in Kitale town. He has been farming for 6 years and has one employee. He sells sheep and cows to the local market. He also earns income from a motorbike business. His main challenge is insecurity in the area.

He recently completed a previous loan from Juhudi Kilimo for Kes.45,000. He has requested this loan from Juhudi for Kes.46,200 to purchase and feed  a dairy cow and start a poultry project as well. This loan will improve his dairy farming and enable him to get good yields that will improve the family's living standards. In future he would like to set up a posho mill (used for grinding maize into flour).

He says that this loan has enabled him to be a successful dairy farmer and in the future to make further loans for development.

loans.use: To purchase and feed a dairy cow and start a poultry project.

loans.name: Ma. Daty

texts.en: Ma. Daty A. is a 42-year-old married woman who lives in Barangay Dungo-an, Manjuyod, Negros Oriental. She earns her living by operating a general store and through her fish-vending business. Ma. Daty's husband, Renaldo, is 46 years old and engages in a business buying and selling livestock. They have two children who are currently going to school and also help their parents in the business as part of their daily chores. Ma. Daty joined NWTF-Project Dungganon (NWTF-PD) in 1999 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by running a general store and engaging in a fish-vending business. Ma. Daty is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 27,000 was used to fund operations of her general store, and it had a positive impact on both the business and on the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing Php 27,000 for her 18th loan which she intends to use on her general store and fish-vending businesses. Ma. Daty is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her general store and fish-vending businesses

loans.name: Celia

texts.en: Celia L. is a 40-year-old married woman who lives in Purok 3 Alim, Hinoba-an, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by buying and selling rice and also by a motorcycle transport and farming businesses. Celia’s husband, Carlito, is a driver and farmer and they have five children: one is already married and four are single. Celia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon (NWTF-PD ) in 2002 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income through her various business activities which now earns her an average monthly income of Php 10,000. Celia is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 21,000 was used to fund operations of her rice sales and farming businesses and it had a positive impact on both the businesses and on the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing Php 23,000 for her 10th loan which she intends to add to the operating capital of her businesses. Celia is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her businesses

loans.name: Dioscora

texts.en: Dioscora S. is a 39-year-old married woman who lives in Barangay Vito, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by fishing. Her husband, Hedrito, who is 43 years old, is a fisherman and they have four adult children. Dioscora joined NWTF-Project Dungganon (NWTF-PD) in 2008 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in a fishing business. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 8,000 from her business activities. Dioscora is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 13,000 was used to fund operations of her fishing business and it had a positive impact on both the business and on her family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing Php 15,000 for her 5th loan which she intends to use to fund her fishing activities. Dioscora is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her business

loans.name: Ma. Luz

texts.en: Ma. Luz A., 50 years old, is a married woman who supports her family by engaging in a fishing and fish-vending business. She lives in Barangay Vito, Sagay City, Negros Occidental, with her husband, Lino, who is a 55-year-old fisherman, and their seven children. Of her children, four are adults and three are of school age. Ma. Luz has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2003 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her fishing and fish-vending business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 8,000. Ma. Luz is now borrowing Php 21,000 so that she can buy materials to repair her fishing boat. This will be her 10th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 19,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Ma. Luz aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To purchase materials to repair her fishing boat

loans.use: To expand her poultry project

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria A. is a 53-year-old married woman who supports her family by engaging in a networking type of business selling a variety of beauty products and ready-to-wear clothes. She lives in Barangay Landangue, Tanjay City, Negros Oriental with her husband and their five adult children. Victoria has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her networking business selling beauty products and ready-to-wear clothes, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 4,000. Victoria is now borrowing Php 28,000 so that she can continue sustaining her business activities. This will be her 10th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 25,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Victoria aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.name: Dolores

texts.en: Dolores M. is a 36-year-old woman who lives in Giligaon, Sta. Catalina, Negros Oriental. She earns her living by operating a general store and by fishing. Her husband, Santiago, is a driver and they have two young children, with one already going to school. Dolores joined NWTF-Project Dungganon (NWTF-PD) in 2000 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by operating a general store and by engaging in a fishing business. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 10,000 from her business activities. Dolores is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 19,500 was used to fund operations of her general store and it had a positive impact on both the business and on the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing Php 25,000 for her 16th loan which she intends to use for her general store and fishing businesses. Dolores is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her businesses

loans.name: Ana

texts.en: Ana I. is a 57-year-old married woman who supports her family by engaging in a bakery business. She lives in Mangnao, Dumaguete City, Negros Oriental, with her husband, Felix, who is a baker, and their three children who are between 32 and 35 years old. Ana has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her bakery business she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 30,000. Ana is now borrowing Php 19,000 as additional working capital for her business. This will be her 8th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 17,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Ana aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her business

loans.name: Susan

texts.en: Susan R. is a 44-year old married woman who lives in Barangay Prosperidad, San Carlos City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by selling fruits and vegetables and by making bags. Her husband, Igmedio, who is 48 years old, helps his wife in running the businesses. They have one child who is 12 years old and currently goes to school. Susan joined NWTF-Project Dungganon (NWTF-PD) in 1998 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by selling fruits and vegetables and by making bags. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 10,000 from her business activities. Susan is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 49,500 was used to fund operations of her fruits and vegetables business as well as her bag-making business and it had a positive impact on both the businesses and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing Php 55,000 for her 18th loan which she intends to use as additional working capital. Susan is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her businesses

loans.name: David Group

texts.en:
Fabiana is the coordinator of David Group and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients generally (many of whom recently emigrated to the Dominican Republic from Haiti). Her group is located in La Romana, a rural area of the country dedicated to the sugar cane harvest, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home there in a simple structure, alone with her two children.

Fabiana is excited to be taking her third loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her sewing business. She plans to use this loan to buy necessary supplies she needs as a seamstress: fabric to make bedding as well as other general supplies.

Fabiana will use the profits to buy a sewing machine for her business and hopes to expand it to include a larger shop with varied products for sale. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy fabric and supplies for her small sewing business

loans.name: Sueños Exitosos Group

texts.es: GLORIA LETICIA T. ES LA PRESIDENTE DEL GRUPO SOLIDARIO LLAMADO SUEÑOS EXITOSOS.  INICIA SU VENTA HACE 3 AÑOS EN SU ALDEA A ORILLAS DE LA CARRETERA ALQUILANDO, HOY DIA ESTA EN SU CASA Y LAS VENTAS HAN AUMENTADO.  SU COMPAÑERO  DE GRUPO ES CARLOS QUIEN ES DUEÑO DE UNA VIDRERIA Y SE DEDICA A LA ELABORACION E INSTALACION DE VENTANAS  Y  TAMBIEN OFELIA QUIEN  VENDE BLUSAS DE TELA DE MANERA  AMBULANTE  EN SU LOCALIDAD.  HAY MUCHAS METAS  Y ELLOS DESEAN EL CREDITO PARA PODE AUMENTAR SU CAPITAL DE TRABAJO LO QUE LES PERMITIRA PODER SURTIR MEJOS SUS NEGOCIOS Y HACER QUE SUS INGRESOS MEJORES, ESO BENEFICIARÀ A SUS FAMILIAS.
texts.en:
Gloria Leticia T. is the president of a support group called Suenos Exitosos ("Making Dreams Come True"). She started in sales 3 years ago, working along the side of a toll road in her town, but she now operates the business in her house and her sales have increased. Her fellow member, Carlos, owns a glass business and earns a living making and installing windows. Another membr, Ofelia, works as a street vendor in her town, selling blouses. Each member has a goal in mind and they are applying for loans to increase their working capital so that they can supply their businesses, increase their incomes and help their families.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Mileidy

texts.es: Mileidy C. J., tiene la edad de 24 años, está soltera, y tiene 1 hijo que es su mayor prioridad. El tiene 5 años. El crédito lo quiere para la compra de una vaca de leche . La idea es tener ganado con producción de leche para consumo propio y para venderla  en la comunidad y así maximizar sus ganancias. Es la primera vez que realiza un crédito con FUDECOSUR y está muy contenta con las facilidades que se le brindaron. Doña Mileidy trabaja desde hace unos años con ganado. Ella espera en un futuro brindarle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida y una mayor estabilidad económica, y de poder seguir creciendo como persona y sobre todo como productora.
texts.en:
Mileidy C. J. is 24 years old and single. She has one child, who is her greatest priority. He is five years old. She wants the loan to buy a dairy cow. The idea is to have livestock that produce milk for their own consumption and to sell in the community. This will maximize her earnings. This is her first loan with Fudecosur. She is very happy with the terms of the loan she got. Mileidy has worked with livestock for years. In the future she hopes to give her family a better quality of life and greater economic stability. She also hopes to be able to continue growing as a person and, above all, as a producer.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a cow

loans.name: Metas Triunfantes Group

texts.es: ANA CRISTINA MAYORGA ES LA REPRESENTANTE DEL GRUPO SOLIDARIO LLAMADO METAS TRIUNFANTES.    ELLA INICIA VENDIENDO PRODUCTO POR  CATALOGO PARA UNA SEÑORA, TIEMPO DESPUES YA LOGRA MANEJAR SU PROPIA MERCADERIA.  CON EL TIEMPO TAMBIEN VENDE BLUSAS DE  TELA.  SU COMPAÑERA MAYRA  VENDE LA ROPA Y CALZADO AMERICANO.  TAMBIEN JULIO CESAR QUIEN ES MIEMBRO DEL BANCO INICIO  SU NEGOCIO EN SU PROPIA CASA CON EL APOYO DE SU MAMA UNICAMENTE, ELLOS NO DEJAN DE SOÑAR CON UN NEGOCIO GRANDE PARA CUMPLIR SUS METAS Y TENER UNA FORMA DE VIDA MEJOR. POR ESO BUSCAN LA OPORTUNIDAD DE CAPITALIZAR SUS NEGOCIOS, POR ESO ES QUE ELLOS SOLICITAN ESTE CRÈDITO PARA PODER INVERTIR Y POCO A POCO HACER REALIDAD SUS SUEÑOS.
texts.en:
Ana Cristina Mayorga represents the Metas Triunfantes group. She started selling products for an employer through a catalogue, but she now handles her own merchandise and also sells wool blouses. Her friend Mayra sells American clothes and shoes. Julio Cesar started his business out of his own home with only the help of his mother, and they never stop dreaming of having a large business to achieve their goals and obtain a better lifestyle. For these reasons, they are all looking for opportunities to expand their businesses. For these reasons, they are requesting this loan in order to be able to invest and, little by little, make their dreams reality.

Translated from Spanish by Christine Cooper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase shoes, sound equipment and television sets

loans.name: Con Dios Adelante (G 3,4, 5) Group

texts.en:
Elena is the coordinator of her group, Con Dios Adelante (With God in the Lead). Her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in La Romana, a rural area of the country dedicated to the sugar cane harvest, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long-time partner and their 4 children.

Elena is excited to be taking her second loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business: purchase clothes, food and other supplies for her small neighborhood convenience store. She will use the profits to improve the lives of her children (by purchasing school supplies, shoes, backpacks) and making improvements to heir home windows. She hopes for  the well-being of her family and to own a larger store in the future. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy supplies (clothes, food) for a small convenience store.

loans.name: Asinio

texts.es: Asinio tiene 29 años, es un joven muy trabajador y responsable, vive en su casa propia y lo que más desea es sobresalir en la vida. Los largos días de trabajo que Asinio realiza en su chacra tanto de café, maíz y achiote, le han servido para obtener los ingresos económicos que necesita para mantenerse. Todas las mañanas sale en dirección a sus cultivos para cuidarlos y trabajarlos, ya que sabe que así obtendrá una cosecha de buena calidad. Lleva 11 años realizando esta actividad y lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es cosechar sus tierras y considera que lo más difícil es fumigar sus tierras. Con el tiempo espera mejorar la calidad de sus productos, fertilizando mejor sus tierras. Este es su tercer crédito con MFP, sabe que tiene que pagar todas sus cuotas puntualmente, si quiere acceder a otro en el futuro. En su grupo comunal, es un socio muy querido, ya que es el más joven del grupo. Con los mil seiscientos nuevos soles que solicita, contratará peones, para que limpien y trabajen sus tierras.
texts.en:
Asinio is 29 years old. He is a very hard-working and responsible young man. He lives in his own house, and what he most desires is to be outstanding in life. The long days of work that Asinio puts in on his farm, where he grows coffee, corn, and achiote, have enabled him to obtain the economic income that he needs to support himself. Every morning he goes out to his crops to take care of them and work on them, since he knows that in this way he will obtain a good quality harvest. He has been doing this work for 11 years, and what he likes most about his work is harvesting his crops, and he considers fumigating his land to be the most difficult task. In time, he hopes to improve the quality of his products by fertilizing his lands better. This is his third loan with MFP, and he knows that he has to make all his payments on time if he wants to be granted another loan in the future. In his community bank, he is a very well-liked member, since he is the youngest in the group. With the 1600 PEN that he is applying for, he will hire workers to clean and work on his land.

Translated from Spanish by Pam McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: hire workers to help him clean and plow his fields

loans.name: Asunciona

texts.es: Asunciona, de 52 años, es una madre de familia muy trabajadora y alegre, vive en su casa propia junto a su esposo Flavio de 65 años y lo que más desea es tener una vejez tranquila. Aunque Asunciona no es Natural de Pichanaki, le ha agarrado mucho cariño a esta tierra, ya que es ahí donde se conoció y se caso con su esposo, 35 años después trabajando juntos en la agricultura han logrado sobresalir y tener unos buenos cultivos de café y plátano. Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es fertilizar sus tierras, lleva 30 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es cosechar sus cultivos. Con el tiempo espera comprar nuevas tierras para incrementar su producción. Este es su tercer crédito con MFP, sabe que tiene que pagar puntualmente sus cuotas y está dispuesta a hacerlo. En su grupo comunal es una socia muy alegre y responsable. Con los tres mil nuevos soles que solicita, comprará más abono e insecticidas para mejorar la calidad de sus tierras.
texts.en:
Asunciona is 52 years old. She is a happy, hard working mother who lives with her husband, 65 year old Flavio, in their own home. She is working toward a peaceful retirement. Even though Asunciona is not a native of Pichanaki, she has taken a liking to this land, especially since this is where she met and married her husband. 35 years later, working together in agriculture, they have managed to have good coffee and banana crops. What she likes most about her work is fertilizing her crops. She also feels that harvesting is the most difficult task. She eventually wants to buy more land in order to increase production. This will be her third loan through MFP and she knows that she must make her payments on time. She is a happy and responsible member of her communal bank. She will use the money from this loan to buy fertilizer and pesticides in order to improve the quality of her land.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Rokhaya

texts.fr: Madame Rokhaya  D.  est une femme de 60 ans qui habite à Ouakam. Elle est sociétaire  de la caisse de l’U-IMCEC depuis un an. Elle a déjà  bénéficié d’un prêt antérieur. Madame D. s’active depuis huit ans dans le commerce  de thioup, thiouraye, tissus, pate d’arachide et autres produits divers. Elle a démarré  ses activités en en achetant des produits  au marche  Sandaga  pour les commercialiser. Ensuite elle a commence à voyager vers la Mauritanie et autres pays limitrophes en vue de diversifier ses produits et maximiser ses profits.  Par conséquent  elle sollicite un crédit  de 500 000 frs dans le but de voyager  et d’acheter des produits de Diaobe et aussi  de la pate d’arachide ceci dans l’objectif de satisfaire sa clientèle. Elle est veuve et en même  temps soutient de famille et ce   financement  pourra lui permettre de renforcer sa capacité de faire face aux besoins de sa famille.
texts.en:
Mrs. Rokhaya D. is a 60-year-old woman who lives in Ouakam. She has been a member of the credit union U-IMCEC for a year. She has already received a previous loan. Mrs. D. has been in the retail business of thioup [indigo dyed fabric], thiouraye [incense], fabric, peanut butter and other products. She started her activity by buying supplies at the Sandaga market to resell them. Later she started to travel to Mauritania and other neighboring countries in order to diversify her products and to maximize her income. She is requesting a loan of 500 000 francs with the goal to travel and buy products from Diaobe and also peanut butter in order to meet her customers’ demand. She is a widow and a family provider and this financing will allow her to boost up her ability to take care of her family’s needs.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To strengthen her working capital

loans.name: Lucero Ma. De Los Ángeles

texts.es:
La señora Lucero Ma. De Los Ángeles F. ha tenido ya un crédito con FVP el cual pago puntualmente.
A su vivienda le está haciendo falta los acabados del interior del cuarto que construyo con el préstamo anterior. Esta solicitando su cooperación para poder terminar la recamara de sus dos pequeños hijos, ya que no cuenta con el dinero necesario para comprar el material y pagarle a la persona que se encargara de realizar la mejora.
Planea pagar el préstamo con una parte del ingreso que recibe su esposo el señor Victor Hugo Guerrero, quien trabaja en una compañía en el área de mantenimiento de maquinaria.
texts.en:
Lucero had one previous loan through MVP and was on time with all of her payments. The room that she built onto her home with the money from her previous loan is still missing the fixtures. She is asking for this loan in order to be able to finish her two young children’s bedroom. At this time she does not have the money to buy the materials and pay for labor. She plans to repay with part of the income that her husband, Victor Hugo, earns as an employee of a machary maintenance company.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Home improvement

loans.name: Dios Proveera (G 1,2,3) Group

texts.en:
GracieL. is the coordinator of her group Dios Proveera (God Will ProviD.). Her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in L. Romana, a rural area of the country dedicated to the sugar cane harvest, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long-term partner and her two children.

GracieL. is excited to be taking her fourth loan with Esperanza  after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her fuel sales business, buying charcoal, gasoline, as well as other general products for resale (beans, etc.) She will use the profits to save money towards setting up a larger place. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy fuel (charcoal, gasoline) and other products (beans, etc.) for resale

loans.name: Isai

texts.es: Isai, de 29 años, es un padre de familia muy amoroso y responsable, vive en su casa propia junto a su esposa Eliana de 28 años y sus 2 queridos hijos, Araceli de 8 y Scott de 4 años, quienes son el principal motivo de todos sus esfuerzos. Con mucho esfuerzo Isai ha logrado sacar adelante sus cafetales, ya que con la ayuda de su esposa a trabajado muy duro y ha logrado que sus productos tenga una muy buena calidad, por este motivo cuando lleva a vender su café a la ciudad de Pichanaki los compradores no dudan en ofrecerle muy buenos precios. Lleva 29 años realizando esta actividad y lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es cuidar sus plantaciones, sin embargo considera que lo más difícil es transportar sus productos hacia los puntos de venta. Con el tiempo, desea comprarse un auto, para transportar él mismo su propia producción. Este es su tercer crédito con MFP, manifiesta que este aporte le ayudará mucho en el progreso de su trabajo. En su grupo comunal, es un socio muy responsable y respetuoso. Con los tres mil nuevos soles que solicita, comprará unas cuantas hectáreas, para plantar plátano.
texts.en:
